=== [[Talk:Gaza genocide#rfc_4B9D749|Talk:Gaza genocide]] expired 2025-02-21 11:01 ===
* Id: 4B9D749
* User: FortunateSons
* Date: 2025-01-28 08:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1272374670|POL 1272374670}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1276890594|POL 1276890594}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Generally speaking, when can views (by experts and "expert activists", such as human rights orgs) be included in the article, and not just in the list? Please vote for the minimal standard you consider due.

# Any reliable source
# [[Wikipedia:EXPERTSPS|expert]] or well-known expert activists, such as major rights organizations 
# 2., but only if cited by RS, peer-reviewed, or comparable
# 2., but only if cited by major RS, peer-reviewed in a major journal that does not primarily publish about the I/P conflict, or comparable
# Experts cited by experts within an academic publication

I believe to have mentioned all significant views, but !voters can and should elaborate on destinctions I may have missed. [[User:FortunateSons|FortunateSons]] ([[User talk:FortunateSons|talk]]) 08:51, 28 January 2025 (UTC)}}

Per the discussion above, it appears that there is an impasse on which sources should be used for the tour dates section. So, it comes to this question: Which is more reliable and should be preferred? Do we use the books ('''The Jacksons: Legacy''' and '''Michael Jackson FAQ''') or the newspapers that claim that shows were on different days. Or should there be a compromise in which both the book(s) and newspapers be used, but in the form of ''efns'' that state that the shows were on different days "according to some sources". Please indicate your preference ("'''Books'''" or "'''Newspapers'''" or "'''Compromise'''") with your reasoning. === [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_E403F0F|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2025-02-23 02:01 ===
* Id: E403F0F
* User: Voorts
* Date: 2025-01-24 01:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1271441354|POLICY 1271441354}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1277165495|POLICY 1277165495}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[WP:ATD-R]] be amended as follows:

{{td|A page can be [[Wikipedia:BLANKANDREDIRECT|blanked and redirected]] if there is a suitable page to redirect to, and if the resulting redirect is not [[Wikipedia:R#DELETE|inappropriate]]. If the change is disputed via a [[Wikipedia:REVERT|reversion]], an attempt should be made to reach a [[Wikipedia:Consensus|consensus]] before blank-and-redirecting again. Suitable venues for doing so include the article's talk page and [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]].|A page can be [[Wikipedia:BLANKANDREDIRECT|blanked and redirected]] if there is a suitable page to redirect to, and if the resulting redirect is not [[Wikipedia:R#DELETE|inappropriate]]. If the change is disputed, such as by [[Wikipedia:REVERT|reversion]], an attempt should be made to reach a [[Wikipedia:Consensus|consensus]] before blank-and-redirecting again. The preferred venue for doing so is the appropriate [[WP:XFD|deletion discussion venue]] for the pre-redirect content, although sometimes the dispute may be resolved on the page's talk page.}}

* Prior discussion: [[Wikipedia talk:Deletion policy#Amending ATD-R]] [[User:Voorts|voorts]] ([[User talk:Voorts|talk]]/[[Special:Contributions/Voorts|contributions]]) 01:54, 24 January 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Lolly Talk#rfc_F24AE3F|Talk:Lolly Talk]] expired 2025-02-26 19:01 ===
* Id: F24AE3F
* User: Herbertman
* Date: 2025-02-26 03:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1277691136|BIO 1277691136}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1277691141|MEDIA 1277691141}}

{{rfcquote|text=
[[User talk:Herbertman|Herbertman]] claimed that their album's physical release has printed as Lolly Management Limited as copyright holder under its Lolly Talk imprint, and they did not signed with Daymaker Creatives, as according to  [https://www.daymakercreatives.com/distribution Daymaker Creatives official website], it just listed them as digital distribution. On the other hand,  [https://www.am730.com.hk/column/%E6%96%B0%E8%81%9E/lolly-talk%E5%92%8Ccollar%E7%9A%84%E5%88%86%E5%88%A5/396815 AM730] article says  "When Lolly Talk was first formed, they did not sign with a major company and claimed to be self-funded. However, in fact, they signed a contract with a company called Daymaker Creatives for the digital distribution of their songs." while streaming services (Apple Music, Spotify etc) noted their copyright as "Daymaker Creatives Limited". Any thoughts? [[Special:Contributions/113.210.105.110|113.210.105.110]] ([[User talk:113.210.105.110|talk]]) 03:09, 26 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Tweet#rfc_A36318D|Template talk:Tweet]] expired 2025-02-27 19:01 ===
* Id: A36318D
* User: Tantomile
* Date: 2025-02-27 09:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1277897439|STYLE 1277897439}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1277897442|POLICY 1277897442}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1277897444|TECH 1277897444}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1277964964|STYLE 1277964964}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1277964967|POLICY 1277964967}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1277964971|TECH 1277964971}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
For years, tweets have commonly been included in articles using the Tweet template, which allows for the [[Tweet (social media)|tweet]]'s content to be displayed within the article in an easy to digest format. The template allows for the name, handle, and photograph of the tweeter to be included with the quote of their tweet. It provides important context to the quote in an easy to understand format, allowing for people to quickly understand that this was a twitter post, rather than a quote from somewhere else. Twitter is commonly used by celebrities, political figures, and other notable people to disperse information quickly and directly to their followers. Twitter's tweets are unique, short messages, so the source of the post is often relevant information, especially when a tweet has a major enough impact on an entity that the tweet itself is notable enough to end up on a Wikipedia page.  

Their have been some discussions about the relevance [[Template talk:Tweet/Archive 1#Box styling|of]] [[Template talk:Tweet/Archive 1#"Verified" sign doesn't belong in Wikipedia articles|this]] [[Template talk:Tweet/Archive 1#"via Twitter"|template]] [[Template talk:Tweet/Archive 1#Font|in]] [[Template talk:Tweet/Archive 1#Does this template have to have verified badges?|the]] [[Template talk:Tweet/Archive 1#Necessity of a template specifically for a tweet|past]], and an RfD was [[Wikipedia:Templates for discussion/Log/2024 May 4#Template:Tweet|held]] in May 2024 with a consensus to keep it as it was at the time. {{ordered list |list-style-type=upper-alpha
| Remove all Twitter/X branding from template but keep overall format the same

| Rework template to be like a normal quote

| Keep template with Twitter/X branding restored }} [[User:Tantomile|Tantomile]] ([[User talk:Tantomile|talk]]) 09:17, 27 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_09DAAAC|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2025-02-28 23:01 ===
* Id: 09DAAAC
* User: Dan Leonard
* Date: 2025-02-14 04:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1275637753|STYLE 1275637753}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1280733304|STYLE 1280733304}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[MOS:INITIALS]] requires stops and spaces between people's initials:
{{blockquote|{{xt|An initial is capitalized and is followed by a [[full point]] (period) and a space (e.g. {{nowrap|[[J. R. R. Tolkien]]}}).}}}}

However, there are seven American political figures known often by their initials in shorthand, and their initials across Wikipedia are used unspaced, in violation of this policy:

# '''FDR''' for [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]
# '''JFK''' for [[John F. Kennedy]]
# '''JFK Jr.''' for [[John F. Kennedy Jr.]]
# '''RFK''' for [[Robert F. Kennedy]]
# '''RFK Jr.''' for [[Robert F. Kennedy Jr.]]
# '''MLK''' for [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]
# '''LBJ''' for [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]

The only exception for spaced initials is given at [[MOS:BIOEXCEPT]], which allows formats such as [[CCH Pounder]] but requires that the format be used only when
{{blockquote|{{bulleted list|{{xt|the person has [[Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published or questionable sources as sources on themselves|clearly declared]] and consistently used a preferred exceptional style for their own name; {{em|and}}|an overwhelming majority of reliable sources use that exceptional style.}}}}}}

While some (but not all) sources currently write these names unspaced, the ''and'' requirement of [[MOS:BIOEXCEPT]] still restricts this usage as none of these men styled their names without spaces, preferring to go by their full names in nearly all cases. In John F. Kennedy's case, there is evidence he wrote his name with spaced initials.<ref name="J. F. K. book cover">{{cite object |description=Book with President Kennedy's initials |inscription=J.&nbsp;F.&nbsp;K. |id=JFKWHP-KN-20381 |author1-first=Robert |author1-last=Knudsen |museum=John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum |exhibition=White House Photographs |url=https://www.jfklibrary.org/asset-viewer/archives/jfkwhp-1962-03-07-f#?image_identifier=JFKWHP-KN-20381}}</ref><ref name="J. F. K. luggage tag">{{cite object |description=Burning Tree Golf Club Bag Tag |inscription=Sen.&nbsp;J.&nbsp;F. Kennedy |id=MO 63.3724.7 |museum=John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum |url=https://jfk.artifacts.archives.gov/objects/13894/burning-tree-golf-club-bag-tag}}</ref>

Some style guides resolve this issue by making a difference in how spaced initials are treated when they are the full name. For instance, Turabian has
{{blockquote|{{xtn|Some individuals are known primarily by initials in place of a first and/or middle name. Such initials should be followed by a period and a space. If you abbreviate an entire name, however, omit periods and spaces.<br />G.&nbsp;K.&nbsp;Chesterton but JFK<br />M.&nbsp;F.&nbsp;K. Fisher but FDR}}}}

A previous discussion at {{section link|Talk:Robert F. Kennedy Jr./Archive_8|"RFK Jr." vs "R. F. K. Jr."}} led to a discussion about modifying BIOEXCEPT at {{section link|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography|MOS:BIOEXCEPT: and/or|nopage=y}}, which was inconclusive.

How should this discrepancy be resolved?
* '''Option 1''': No change to the MOS, '''update all pages to use spaced initials'''.
* '''Option 2: Modify [[MOS:INITIALS]]''' to add {{xt|If you abbreviate an entire name, however, omit periods and spaces}} from Turabian.
* '''Option 3: Modify [[MOS:BIOEXCEPT]]''' to remove the {{xt!|''and''}}-test and replace it with {{xt|''or''}}.
* '''Option 4''': As these examples are all Americans, '''deem this a [[MOS:ENGVAR]] issue''' and leave current styles intact.
* '''Option 5''' "Ignore the MOS if it is not helpful." (Added by Polygnotus without any explanation of what that's supposed to mean operationally.)
* '''Option 6''' ""Periods may be omitted when a person's full name is consistently abbreviated to just their initials, for instance MLK for Martin Luther King, Jr., if the common version of the abbreviation consistently appears without periods." (Added by SportingFlyer.)
‚Äî <span title="Signature of Dan Leonard">[[User:Dan Leonard|Dan Leonard]] ([[User talk:Dan Leonard|talk]]&nbsp;‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/Dan Leonard|contribs]])</span> 04:22, 14 February 2025 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_458EDD9|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2025-02-28 23:01 ===
* Id: 458EDD9
* User: Surtsicna
* Date: 2025-01-29 22:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1272710238|STYLE 1272710238}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1278181704|STYLE 1278181704}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[MOS:JOBTITLES]] currently reads:

{{quote|Offices, titles, and positions ... are common nouns and therefore should be in lower case when used generically. They are capitalized only in the following cases:
#When followed by a person's name to form a title, i.e., when they can be considered to have become part of the name: {{xt|President Nixon}}, not {{!xt|president Nixon}}; {{xt|Pope John XXIII}}, not {{!xt|pope John XXIII}}.
#When a title is used to refer to a specific person as a substitute for their name during their time in office, e.g., {{xt|the King}}, not {{!xt|the king}} (referring to [[Charles&nbsp;III]]); {{xt|the Pope}}, not {{!xt|the pope}} (referring to [[Pope Francis|Francis]]).
#When a formal title for a specific entity (or conventional translation thereof) is addressed as a title or position in and of itself, is not plural, is not preceded by a modifier (including a definite or indefinite article), and is not a reworded description}}
Should we simplify [[MOS:JOBTITLES]] by removing exceptions #2 and/or #3? [[User:Surtsicna|Surtsicna]] ([[User talk:Surtsicna|talk]]) 22:52, 29 January 2025 (UTC)}}

* User: WeatherWriter
* Date: 2025-02-25 03:40:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1277524390|HIST 1277524390}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1277524391|POL 1277524391}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1277524393|STYLE 1277524393}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1278365747|HIST 1278365747}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1278365750|POL 1278365750}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1278365759|STYLE 1278365759}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What should the section regarding ''[[HuffPost]]'''s report on February 14 be titled?

*'''Option 1''' &ndash; "Alleged leak of classified intelligence"
*'''Option 2''' &ndash; "Leak of intelligence not intended for public release"
*'''Option 3''' &ndash; Another name choice (Please stated additional name choice with this option).

'''Brief background''': On February 14 ''[[HuffPost]]'' [https://www.huffpost.com/entry/elon-musk-doge-posts-classified-data_n_67ae646de4b0513a8d767112 published a story] indicating DOGE displayed "classified data" on their website. This story and information was subsequently the subject of numberous news articles and led to a section being created in the article called "{{tq|Leak of classified intelligence}}". On February 21, [[Reuters]] [https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-spy-agency-data-doge-website-was-unclassified-not-meant-public-release-2025-02-21/ reported] the data was not classified at all, but "was not intended for public release". This new Reuters report led to a disagreement between editors regarding the most appropriate section name. '''The [[User:WeatherWriter|Weather Event Writer]]''' ([[User talk:WeatherWriter|Talk Page)]] 03:40, 25 February 2025 (UTC)}}

The Language section is excessively long and provides copious amounts of technical information that isn‚Äôt appropriate when pages like [[C++ syntax]] exists (it was previously a redirect page to this section, but there is no reason to leave it as a redirect when such a page could be expanded to contain the technical information). Therefore I propose that the section should be cleared or at least simplified enough to shorten and keep the technical details to the dedicated page. === [[Talk:Coefficient of relationship#rfc_279E644|Talk:Coefficient of relationship]] expired 2025-03-08 20:01 ===
* Id: 279E644
* User: MrOllie
* Date: 2025-03-08 18:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1279465955|SCI 1279465955}}
* RFC Text:

{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1740283273}}
Should this article contain a table of degrees of relationship with calculated coefficients of relationship, such as the one at [[Coefficient_of_relationship#Human_relationships]]? 

'''Relisting''' this RFC, in honor of the recent addition of 'sexadecuple-fourth cousin' to the table. Hopefully we'll get some participation this time. - [[User:MrOllie|MrOllie]] ([[User talk:MrOllie|talk]]) 18:20, 8 March 2025 (UTC)}}

Louis Wain having schizophrenia is speculation done after his death, as his official diagnosis ‚Äîwhile he was alive‚Äî was only of insanity. [https://artincontext.org/louis-wain/#Louis_Wains_Art_Style_and_Mental_Condition (1)]

=== [[Talk:Christopher Columbus#rfc_84ED01D|Talk:Christopher Columbus]] expired 2025-03-10 21:01 ===
* Id: 84ED01D
* User: Pipo1955
* Date: 2025-03-10 19:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1279823235|HIST 1279823235}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1279831676|HIST 1279831676}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

There has been an ongoing discussion regarding the use of the link to "[[Italians]]" in the Christopher Columbus article. Some editors argue that this link is anachronistic and does not reflect how Columbus or his contemporaries identified him, while others believe it is a valid descriptor based on modern labeling.  

The purpose of this RFC is to determine whether the link "[[Italians]]" should be retained, modified, or reconsidered in order to ensure historical accuracy and compliance with Wikipedia‚Äôs core policies on [[WP:V]] (Verifiability), [[WP:SYNTH]] (No Original Synthesis) and [[WP:BURDEN]] (Burden of Proof)

---
* '''Background'''

- The '''most widely accepted hypothesis''' regarding Columbus‚Äôs origin is that he was born in '''Genoa''', an independent republic at the time.  

- Columbus '''explicitly referred to himself as Genovese''', never as Italian.  

- There is no known evidence that Columbus ever spoke or wrote in Italian. No contemporary documents explicitly refer to him as "Italian"; instead, they consistently '''describe him as Genovese'''. 

- The '''concept of a [[Unification of Italy|unified Italy]] did not exist in Columbus‚Äôs lifetime'''.  At the time, the Italian peninsula consisted of multiple independent states, including the Republic of Genoa.  

- Many historians classify Columbus as Genovese and '''question the use of "Italian" as a historically accurate label'''. 

- Despite this, '''modern sources frequently refer to Columbus as "Italian",''' and he is often claimed by Italians as part of their historical and cultural legacy. 

- '''The use of "Italians" in the article may constitute a retrospective application of a modern label''', raising concerns about [[WP:V]] (Verifiability) and [[WP:SYNTH]] (No Original Synthesis).  

---
*'''Discussion question'''

Considering Wikipedia‚Äôs policies on Burden of Proof ([[WP:BURDEN]]), verifiability ([[WP:V]]) and no original synthesis ([[WP:SYNTH]]), should the link to "[[Italians]]" remain in the article as a descriptor for Columbus, or should it be:  

*1. '''Retained''' as is, with proper sourcing.  
*2. '''Nuanced''' to reflect historical context and avoid anachronism.  
*3. Placed in '''quotation marks''' to indicate its retrospective nature.  
*4. '''Removed''' if it is found to be inconsistent with contemporary sources.  

Please provide policy-based arguments and reliable sources to support your position. [[User:Pipo1955|Pipo1955]] ([[User talk:Pipo1955|talk]]) 19:58, 10 March 2025 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the [[Demonym|gentilic]] (adjective and noun) form of the country [[Botswana]] be written on Wikipedia articles?
:'''A''': ''[[Wikt:Botswanan|Botswanan]]'' ({{abbr|pl.|plural}} ''Botswanans'') in all cases, without exception
:'''B''': ''[[Wikt:Motswana|Motswana]]'' (pl. ''Batswana'') in all cases, without exception
:'''C''': ''Motswana'' in articles with [[MOS:TIES|strong national ties]] to Botswana or South Africa, otherwise ''Botswanan''
:'''D''': [[MOS:Retain|Retain]] whichever word is used first in the article, either ''Botswanan'' or ''Motswana''
‚Äï<span style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 1px; border-radius: 5px;">[[User:Howardcorn33|<b>Howard</b>]] ‚Ä¢ [[User talk:Howardcorn33|üåΩ<sup>33</sup>]]</span> 12:02, 15 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:United States#rfc_83E9272|Talk:United States]] expired 2025-03-16 04:01 ===
* Id: 83E9272
* User: AG202
* Date: 2025-03-02 03:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1278385595|LANG 1278385595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1278385601|POL 1278385601}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1284855214|LANG 1284855214}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1284855218|POL 1284855218}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
An Executive Order was signed today, March 1, by President Trump titled [https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/designating-english-as-the-official-language-of-the-united-states/ "Designating English as the Language of the United States"]. The main portions of note are within Section 3. Designating an Official Language for the United States:
* "(a)  English is the official language of the United States."
* "(b) [[Executive Order 13166]] of August 11, 2000 (Improving Access to Services for Persons with Limited English Proficiency), is hereby revoked; nothing in this order, however, requires or directs any change in the services provided by any agency.  Agency heads should make decisions as they deem necessary to fulfill their respective agencies' mission and efficiently provide Government services to the American people.  Agency heads are not required to amend, remove, or otherwise stop production of documents, products, or other services prepared or offered in languages other than English."

That being said, Executive Orders are not legislation and are limited to the Executive Branch's interpretation of existing law. They can also be overturned by the next president. This EO also seems to be largely symbolic and does not require any substantial changes to federal programs per [https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/01/us/politics/trump-order-english-official-language.html the NYT], except that agencies are no longer required to support "programs for people with limited English proficiency" per [https://www.npr.org/2025/03/01/nx-s1-5313883/trump-english-official-language-executive-order NPR]. Usually, from what I can tell as well, official languages of countries are designated either in a country's constitution or through the legislative process. 

There have also been attempts to codify English as the official language through legislative means with more teeth, force of law, and would require official documents, laws, communications, and such, to be in English, as mentioned in the article [[English Language Unity Act]] and as seen by [https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/997/text H.R. 997 from the 118th Congress], but those efforts have never been signed into law. However, there is an argument that the Executive Branch could set policy in this space, though it is unprecedented. There's also a middle ground, such as including a note stating that "English is the official language of the Executive Branch per EO [number], but is not stated in the constitution or in federal law", similar to the way that we currently do for states. There's also an argument to wait and see how folks react. As such here are the options I envisioned, though I am open to other options.

Should we include "English" as the official language of the United States?
* '''A''': Yes, with no qualifications.
* '''B''': No, keep prior status quo.
* '''C''': Yes, with the qualifier that it is not mentioned in the Constitution or in applicable legislation.
* '''D''': State that there is no ''de jure'' official language, but mention that an official language has been set by the Executive Branch.
* '''E''': Wait.

Note that there is another RFC taking place at {{section link|Talk:Languages_of_the_United_States#English_as_official_language}} [[User:AG202|AG202]] ([[User talk:AG202|talk]]) 03:31, 2 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:United States#rfc_515C000|Talk:United States]] expired 2025-03-16 04:01 ===
* Id: 515C000
* User: Chetsford
* Date: 2025-02-14 03:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1275632002|POL 1275632002}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1280728505|POL 1280728505}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should Elon Musk's name and title or non-title be listed in some form (the details of which should be determined through a separate discussion) in the list of principal officials in the ''Government'' section of the infobox? 

:'''A.''' Yes
:'''B.''' Yes, if a descriptive sentence exists in the body of the article
:'''C.''' No
:'''D.''' Other
[[User:Chetsford|Chetsford]] ([[User talk:Chetsford|talk]]) 03:50, 14 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_4868C66|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2025-03-16 05:01 ===
* Id: 4868C66
* User: GRuban
* Date: 2025-02-25 21:35:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1277646772|BIO 1277646772}}

{{rfcquote|text=
[[MOS:NICKNAME]] says: "If a person is known by a nickname used in lieu of or in addition to a given name, and it is not a common hypocorism of one of their names, or a professional alias, it is usually presented between double quotation marks following the last given name or initial." Does that apply only to nicknames that are our article titles, or to all nicknames that are sufficiently prominent to be in the lead sentence? --[[User:GRuban|GRuban]] ([[User talk:GRuban|talk]]) 21:35, 25 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Israeli bombing of the Gaza Strip#rfc_CE3905E|Talk:Israeli bombing of the Gaza Strip]] expired 2025-03-16 16:01 ===
* Id: CE3905E
* User: Johnadams11
* Date: 2025-02-14 15:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1275706065|HIST 1275706065}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1275706068|POL 1275706068}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1280809740|HIST 1280809740}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1280809745|POL 1280809745}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Given the importance of the bombings of Dresden, Hamburg, and London to the lede of this article, it has been proposed that the combined death toll (102,000) of those bombings be added as well.

See previous discussion [[Talk:Israeli bombing of the Gaza Strip#Historical Comparators: Hamburg, Dresden, London|here]].

Options:
# No Change
# Add "The combined death toll in the WWII bombings of Dresden, Hamburg, and London was 102,000 <ref>{{Cite web |last=Dresden |date=2025-02-07 |title=Dresden historical commission publishes final report |url=https://www.dresden.de/en/city/07/03/historical_commission.php |access-date=2025-02-08 |website=www.dresden.de |language=en}}</ref><ref name="NatGeo">{{cite web |url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/history/article/the-bombing-of-hamburg-foreshadowed-the-horrors-of-hiroshima |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210722181412/https://www.nationalgeographic.com/history/article/the-bombing-of-hamburg-foreshadowed-the-horrors-of-hiroshima |url-status=dead |archive-date=22 July 2021 |work=[[National Geographic]] |title=The bombing of Hamburg foreshadowed the horrors of Hiroshima |first=Erin |last=Blakemore |date=22 July 2021}}</ref><ref>Richards, Denis. *Royal Air Force 1939‚Äì1945: The Fight at Odds*, vol. I, London: HMSO, 1974 (orig. 1953), p. 217. [http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/UN/UK/UK-RAF-I/UK-RAF-I-7.html]</ref>" (A Routine Calculation under [[Wikipedia:No original research#Routine calculations|WP:OR]].)
# Remove comparisons with WWII bombings
[[User:Johnadams11|Johnadams11]] ([[User talk:Johnadams11|talk]]) 15:57, 14 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:COVID-19 lab leak theory#rfc_CA2F482|Talk:COVID-19 lab leak theory]] expired 2025-03-17 03:01 ===
* Id: CA2F482
* User: Red Slash
* Date: 2025-03-17 01:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1280899624|SCI 1280899624}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1280899628|POL 1280899628}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1280906031|SCI 1280906031}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1280906033|POL 1280906033}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article began in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19_lab_leak_theory&oldid=1005881401 early 2021]. Within two weeks (at [[COVID-19 misinformation]]), an [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:COVID-19_misinformation/Archive_9#RFC_to_fix_this_once_and_for_all RfC was held] to determine whether the lab leak theory should be called a "minority, but scientific viewpoint" or a "conspiracy theory". (No consensus was found.)

Since then, many scientists have weighed in on the issue, but intelligence agencies have, as well. The [https://apnews.com/article/covid-cia-trump-china-pandemic-lab-leak-9ab7e84c626fed68ca13c8d2e453dde1 CIA] and the [https://www.dw.com/en/covid-pandemic-likely-caused-by-wuhan-lab-accident-fbi/a-64848898 FBI under Joe Biden] have both publicly announced that they consider the lab leak to be the most likely possibility (the CIA is mildly confident, the FBI moreso). This week, the [https://www.dw.com/en/covid-pandemic-likely-unleashed-by-lab-mishap-germanys-bnd/a-71897701 German spy agency] has been reported by Reuters to have a fairly high level of confidence that the virus came from a lab.

How, then, should the lab leak theory be addressed, in both the lead and the body of this article?

'''Status Quo'''. Keep essentially the same: {{quote|The COVID-19 lab leak theory, or lab leak hypothesis, is the idea that SARS-CoV-2, the virus that caused the COVID-19 pandemic, came from a laboratory. This claim is highly controversial; most scientists believe the virus spilled into human populations through natural zoonosis ... similar to the SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV outbreaks, and consistent with other pandemics in human history. Available evidence suggests that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was originally harbored by bats, and spread to humans from infected wild animals ... There is no evidence SARS-CoV-2 existed in any laboratory prior to the pandemic ... Many scenarios proposed for a lab leak are characteristic of conspiracy theories. Central to many is a misplaced suspicion based on the proximity of the outbreak to the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV), where coronaviruses are studied.}}

2. '''Treated as at least equally likely'''. Change the wording to reflect a (relatively) higher likelihood of the virus having in fact leaked from a laboratory: perhaps something like {{quote|The COVID-19 lab leak theory, or lab leak hypothesis, is the idea that SARS-CoV-2, the virus that caused the COVID-19 pandemic, came from a laboratory. This claim has been hotly debated over the years since the initial outbreak of the virus. Initially, many scientists believed that the virus had spilled into human populations through natural zoonosis ... similar to the SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV outbreaks, and consistent with other pandemics in human history. However, multiple intelligence agencies have since asserted, with varying levels of confidence, that a leak is in fact the most likely scenario to have occurred. The lab leak theory was initially criticized and dismissed by some as a conspiracy theory due to its contravention of the initial scientific consensus; however...}}

3. '''Somewhere in between''', perhaps something like {{quote|The COVID-19 lab leak theory, or lab leak hypothesis, is the idea that SARS-CoV-2, the virus that caused the COVID-19 pandemic, came from a laboratory. This claim, while initially rejected by most scientists, has since been considered to be at least somewhat likely by the FBI and CIA. Initially, many scientists believed that the virus had spilled into human populations through natural zoonosis ... similar to the SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV outbreaks, and consistent with other pandemics in human history. The lab leak theory was initially criticized and dismissed by some as a conspiracy theory due to its contravention of the initial scientific consensus; however...}}

(Note: A previous RfC on this topic was summarily closed by an editor who strongly prefers the status quo (and who has made several edits elsewhere on this talk page to that end). He called it a "biased" RfC without providing any evidence or explanation of bias. I have therefore proposed the RfC again, and would request it to stay the full 30 days, and would certainly ask for '''any closing editor to be someone who has not already publicly shown a clear point of view on the topic.''') [[User:Red Slash|<span style="color:#FF4131;">Red</span>]] [[User talk:Red Slash|<b><span style="color:#460121;">Slash</span></b>]] 01:47, 17 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_C31EEEE|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2025-03-20 17:01 ===
* Id: C31EEEE
* User: Arkenstrone
* Date: 2025-03-20 04:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1281406551|RELI 1281406551}}
* RFC Text:

Is the article by Miesel [https://www.catholicworldreport.com/2021/09/14/a-monument-to-pseudo-religiosity-a-case-against-the-poem-of-the-man-god/] a reliable source for the [[Poem of the Man-God]] criticism section, when it contains multiple factual historical errors concerning the actions of the Catholic Church in relation to Valtorta's work?
Miesel admits in her article that she is a laywoman and not a theologian. She then states:

"Furthermore, on April 17, 1993, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith directed the Italian Bishops‚Äô Conference to order this disclaimer placed in future re-issues of the Poem: ‚Äú‚Ä¶the ‚Äòvisions‚Äô and ‚Äòdictations‚Äô referred to in it are simply literary forms used by the author to narrate in her own way the life of Jesus. They cannot be considered supernatural in origin."

That is incorrect. Catholic scholar and theologian Fr. Anthony Pillari clearly states that this was Ratzinger's personal opinion and not that of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, which had not held formal discussions on the issue, and hence had no juridic value.[https://doi.org/10.20381/ruor-21436]

In addition, the text to which Miesel is confusedly referring to was a letter from Cardinal Tettamanzi who wrote to Emilio Pisani, the publisher of the Poem, requesting that a disclaimer be placed on the work. Once again, Fr. Anthony Pillari states that was the personal opinion of Tettamanzi, not of the Catholic Conference of Bishops, since no formal meeting was recorded as having taken place on the subject, which therefore caused Tettamanzi's position to have no juridic value.[https://doi.org/10.20381/ruor-21436]

With such basic errors in reporting multiple important historical facts, does Miesel's article adhere to [[WP:RS]]?

For more information, please see this [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:The_Poem_of_the_Man-God#'Criticism'_section_could_do_with_some_cleaning_up talk page] for the discussion leading up to this RfC. [[User:Arkenstrone|Arkenstrone]] ([[User talk:Arkenstrone|talk]]) 04:45, 20 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers#rfc_7EAACBC|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers]] expired 2025-03-24 13:01 ===
* Id: 7EAACBC
* User: Nikoledood
* Date: 2025-02-22 12:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1277066551|MEDIA 1277066551}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1282117475|MEDIA 1282117475}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1282117481|STYLE 1282117481}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1282117484|POLICY 1282117484}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Film gauge is a measure of the width of photo and movie films, and is written as the width of the film in millimeters followed by the unit ‚Äúmm‚Äù. Film gauges can be written either with a space (35{{nbsp}}mm film), without a space (35mm film), or with a hyphen (35-mm film).

In the context of film gauges, should Wikipedia:
{{ordered list |list-style-type=upper-alpha
| always use a non-breaking space (35{{nbsp}}mm film)
| always use no space (35mm film)
| always use a hyphen (35-mm film)
| let editors use their own judgement }}

and...

Should a statement specifying which style to use be added to [[MOS:NUM]] under the [[MOS:NUM#Specific units | Specific units]] section, and/or to [[MOS:FILM]] under the [[MOS:FILM#Guidelines for related topics | Guidelines for related topics]] section? ~ [[User:Nikoledood|Nikoledood]] ([[User talk:Nikoledood|talk]]) 12:28, 22 February 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_BF2834F|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2025-03-27 22:01 ===
* Id: BF2834F
* User: Neegzistuoja
* Date: 2025-03-18 09:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1281105935|BIO 1281105935}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1281105941|STYLE 1281105941}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1286038864|STYLE 1286038864}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
As per [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Indigenous peoples of Australia#First Nations group names in the first sentence of bio articles?]]: 

A: Can belonging to an [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal Australian]] or [[Torres Strait Islanders|Torres Strait Islander]] group be considered a form of [[nationality]]?

B: Should [[MOS:NATIONALITY]] be edited to include an example of someone belonging to an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander nation with that nationality named as a demonym in the first sentence of the lead, similarly to the example given for Native Americans and Indigenous Canadians? E.g. the first sentence of the [[Ashleigh Barty]] article reads: 

{{tq|'''Ashleigh Jacinta Barty''' {{post-nominals|size=100%|country=AUS|AO}} (born 24 April 1996) is an Australian ([[Ngarigo]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2021/jul/10/grounded-and-meticulous-ash-barty-writing-tennis-history-of-her-own|title=Grounded and meticulous Ash Barty writing tennis history of her own|first=Richard|last=Evans|work=The Guardian|date=10 July 2021|quote=Barty, a Ngarigo woman and deeply proud of her Indigenous heritage}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/sport/tennis/open-hearts-indigenous-kids-bring-joy-for-barty-goolagong-cawley-20230118-p5cdil.html|title=Open hearts: Indigenous kids bring joy for Barty, Goolagong Cawley|first=Scott|last=Spits|work=The Age|date=18 January 2023|quote=Ngarigo woman Barty admitted it felt ‚Äúa bit strange‚Äù to be back in Melbourne with a relaxed frame of mind}}</ref>) former professional [[tennis]] player and [[cricket]]er.}}

[[User:Neegzistuoja|Neegzistuoja]] ([[User talk:Neegzistuoja|talk]]) 09:09, 18 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Copts#rfc_E1852C2|Talk:Copts]] expired 2025-03-30 05:01 ===
* Id: E1852C2
* User: Epenkimi#Regarding the edits
* Date: 2025-03-29 16:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1282962440|SOC 1282962440}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1284130960|SOC 1284130960}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The article exhibits significant issues with the framing of its content, demonstrating a clear bias towards certain identity-based conclusions. This bias is evident in how specific claims are presented, particularly regarding the relationship to ancient Egypt. There is a strong overemphasis on unverified statements, such as "Copts are the direct descendants of the Ancient Egyptians," which lack credible academic sources and misrepresent genetic history. Furthermore, vague and oversimplified language like "Coptic music is a continuation of ancient Egyptian music" and "Coptic culture is considered a continuation of that of ancient Egypt" diminishes the complexity of these cultural histories and risks misleading readers. 

Such claims in the article are backed by self-published sources, qualitative studies from unrelated fields, and even [[WP:OR]]. My own attempts to address these issues have been largely reverted, leaving them pervasive throughout the article. The editor heavily involved in the article insists on including such statements, stating that they are established facts, and has repeated them throughout the text. The quality of the article, which was previously a good article nominee, has, unfortunately, deteriorated significantly due to a lack of consideration for [[WP:MOS]]. Extensive discussion available in the talk page and the talk page of the other editor ([[User talk:Epenkimi#Regarding the edits|here]]). [[User:Turnopoems|Turnopoems]] ([[User talk:Turnopoems|talk]]) 16:43, 29 March 2025 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should AI-generated images be banned from use in articles? (Where "AI-generated" means  wholly created by generative AI, not a human-created image that has been modified with AI tools.) 06:25, 28 February 2025 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1278372847|LANG 1278372847}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1283365780|LANG 1283365780}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1283365784|POL 1283365784}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
On March 1, 2025, President [[Donald Trump]] has signed and published the [[executive order]] "Designating English as the Official Language of The United States". The full text is available [https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/designating-english-as-the-official-language-of-the-united-states/ here]. This has been [[WP:BOLD]]ly reflected in the article, but since it is likely to be challenged by some editors, I'm creating this [[WP:RFC|request for comment]] to get consensus on how we should handle this.

The order plainly states that it makes no ''legal'' change except for rescinding [[Executive Order 13166]]; agencies are no longer required to provide services or documents in languages other than English, but are not directed to necessarily make any changes.

The order does designate English as the United States' official language, even if no changes to the legal code have been made. <span lang="en">&mdash;&nbsp;[[:User:Gabldotink|gabldotink]] <small>[&nbsp;[[:User talk:Gabldotink|talk]]&nbsp;&#124;&nbsp;[[:Special:Contributions/Gabldotink|contribs]]&nbsp;&#124;&nbsp;[[m:Special:CentralAuth/Gabldotink|global account]]&nbsp;]</small></span> 01:57, 2 March 2025 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the page titled "Xkcd" be moved to "XKCD", to change how the title is displayed to the user across Wikipedia and more? While the article itself uses the [[WP:DISPLAYTITLE]] magic word to display "''xkcd''" all-lowercase, other places, including Wikipedia categories and Wikipedia search results, currently show the capitalization "Xkcd", which is much less common than "XKCD". This proposal concerns at least five different policy and technical pages, yet none seem to resolve the dispute. 17:32, 2 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Denali#rfc_9737D9F|Talk:Denali]] expired 2025-04-03 22:01 ===
* Id: 9737D9F
* User: Jibolba
* Date: 2025-03-21 22:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1281696205|STYLE 1281696205}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1283828063|STYLE 1283828063}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article does not follow [[WP:COMMONNAME]]. I would point people to the precedents set by the move request from the name Bangalore to [[Bengaluru]] in 2024: [[Talk:Bengaluru#c-Sceptre-20241122204400-Requesting move from Bangalore to Bengaluru|Here]]. 
Realistically, Bangalore is far more commonly used name both worldwide and in India. Regardless, that is an essentially anecdotal, subjective statement and there exists a WP standard for this reason. The Bengaluru moves adheres to the standard.

This article adhered to the standard when it changed to 'Denali' in 2015. It currently does not. It is factually true that the [https://www.ap.org/the-definitive-source/announcements/ap-style-guidance-on-gulf-of-mexico-mount-mckinley/ AP] as well as [https://x.com/britannica/status/1889724479967830244?s=46 Britannica] are following the federal name change. This is not to mention that every map of the world in every textbook and atlas used in US schools from 1896 to 2015 used Mt. McKinley. I don't believe it is unreasonable to assume this to be proof of a status quo. The Obama name change was an obvious deviation from this well established status quo of more than a century ‚Äì Wikipedia followed it still, as it was in accordance with COMMONNAME standards. 

I would like to understand why that same standard is not being applied presently. We are either to say the COMMONNAME rules are in need of relitigation, or the article title must be changed to 'Mt. McKinley'. [[User:Jibolba|Jibolba]] ([[User talk:Jibolba|talk]]) 22:35, 21 March 2025 (UTC)}}

Hi all, I want to gather consensus to change the links of the leads of the articles that currently exist in [[List of rugby union clubs in Germany]]. === [[Wikipedia talk:Notability#rfc_6EAC5E3|Wikipedia talk:Notability]] expired 2025-04-10 02:01 ===
* Id: 6EAC5E3
* User: Mrfoogles
* Date: 2025-04-04 18:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1283961561|POLICY 1283961561}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1284843165|POLICY 1284843165}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the term "notability" be replaced with the term "suitability" (as in "a suitable topic") or "eligibility" (as in "an eligible topic"), over a transitional period, in order to reduce newcomer confusion? During the three-month transitional period, the new term would be mentioned as an alternative. Then, it would replace the old term in policies and guidelines, and "notability" would be mentioned as an alternative. [[User:Mrfoogles|Mrfoogles]] ([[User talk:Mrfoogles|talk]]) 18:32, 4 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Donald Trump#rfc_448DCC2|Talk:Donald Trump]] expired 2025-04-10 08:01 ===
* Id: 448DCC2
* User: Riposte97
* Date: 2025-03-11 07:24:00

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the sentence on the Unite the Right rally include more context?
<br>
'''Current wording:''' Trump's comments on the 2017 [[Unite the Right rally]], condemning "this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides" and stating that there were "very fine people on both sides", were criticized as implying a [[moral equivalence]] between the [[white supremacist]] demonstrators and the counter-protesters.
<br>
'''Proposed wording:''' Following the 2017 [[Unite the Right rally]], Trump condemned "this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides." On another occasion, he said that there were "very fine people on both sides," though said in the same statement that "I'm not talking about the neo-Nazis and the white nationalists, because they should be condemned totally." His comments were criticized as implying a [[moral equivalence]] between the [[white supremacist]] demonstrators and the counter-protesters. [[User:Riposte97|Riposte97]] ([[User talk:Riposte97|talk]]) 07:24, 11 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Advans#rfc_D818A35|Talk:Advans]] expired 2025-04-10 18:01 ===
* Id: D818A35
* User: Solenereboulet
* Date: 2025-04-10 16:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1284934740|ECON 1284934740}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1284943141|ECON 1284943141}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

''' RFC: Review of multiple proposed edits (conflict of interest declared) '''

<!-- [[User:DoNotArchiveUntil]] 17:01, 15 May 2025 (UTC) -->{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1747328475}}
Hello everyone,

As a paid contributor with a declared conflict of interest, I have suggested several improvements and updates to the Advans article on this [[Talk:Advans|Talk page]] over the past few weeks. In accordance with Wikipedia‚Äôs COI and paid contribution guidelines, I have not edited the article directly and have instead submitted all proposed changes here for review and consensus.

I am now requesting a community review of the set of proposals listed throughout this [[Talk:Advans|Talk page]]. These edits cover the following topics:

- Clarification of Advans' history, including its international operations and divestments in Asia (Cambodia, Pakistan, Myanmar).
- Addition of verified information on client protection certifications received by subsidiaries (Amret and Advans Tunisia), based on independent audits.
- Integration of information related to the El Baya loan product for women entrepreneurs in Tunisia, in partnership with GIZ.
- Updates on the group‚Äôs climate resilience strategy and its financial inclusion goals.
- Minor structural and wording adjustments for clarity and neutrality.


I would greatly appreciate feedback from other editors regarding the suitability, neutrality, and encyclopedic value of these proposed additions.

Thank you in advance for your time and guidance! [[User:Solenereboulet|Solenereboulet]] ([[User talk:Solenereboulet|talk]]) 16:11, 10 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_8E712EA|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2025-04-14 10:01 ===
* Id: 8E712EA
* User: Abayomi2003
* Date: 2025-03-22 18:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1281825605|SOC 1281825605}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1286307639|SOC 1286307639}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
''[https://knowyourmeme.com/ Know Your Meme]'' (KYM) is a website dedicated to documenting internet memes and viral phenomena. According to their [https://knowyourmeme.com/about About page], {{tq|Know Your Meme's research is handled by an independent professional editorial and research staff and community members.}} The site features different categories of entries, including those marked as "Confirmed," which according to KYM have been carefully researched and verified by the research staff.

Currently, KYM is listed among user-generated content sources considered generally unreliable per [[WP:UGC]]. This RFC seeks to determine whether "Confirmed" articles on KYM, which have undergone editorial review and fact-checking by staff, should be considered reliable sources for limited use in Wikipedia articles about internet memes and web culture.

''' Proposal (KYM) '''

Little discussion has been had about KYM articles marked as "Confirmed" in the past. The last time this was discussed was [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_293#Citing_individual_Youtube_reviews_and_Know_Your_Meme 5 years ago], though this was when there was no information about KYM's editorial process or staff, and the result of the discussion was still unclear. Since then, KYM has developed a more robust editorial process with clear guidelines for verification and fact-checking, as outlined on their [https://knowyourmeme.com/editorials/rules-and-guidelines/ Editorial Rules] page. The site now has an established team of professional editors with specific roles and responsibilities, and their "Confirmed" status has become a meaningful indicator of editorial review rather than merely user-generated content.

I propose that KYM articles '''clearly marked as "Confirmed" or written by staff (e.g. [https://trending.knowyourmeme.com/news/rumored-dan-hentschel-tv-show-on-max-has-fans-on-twitter-excited-but-it-seems-to-be-a-lie])''' may be used as reliable sources for limited purposes in Wikipedia, specifically:

* For articles about internet memes and web culture
* When properly attributed (e.g., "According to ''Know Your Meme''...")
* For factual information about the origin, spread, and evolution of memes
* Not for use in [[WP:BLP|biographies of living persons]]
* Not to be used in Wikipedia's voice ([[WP:WIKIVOICE]])

KYM's editorial process for "Confirmed" articles involves fact-checking and verification by professional staff. Their [https://knowyourmeme.com/guidelines guidelines] state that {{tq|''Know Your Meme'' staff review and fact-check content thoroughly}} and that they {{tq|are careful to cite only reliable sources and strive to provide an impartial and balanced variety of perspectives.}} Their [https://knowyourmeme.com/editorials/rules-and-guidelines/ editorial guidelines] clearly state the dos-and-dont's before a submission is {{tq|properly researched and eventually confirmed}}.

This RFC does not propose any changes to the status of KYM articles marked as "Submission" or "Deadpool", which would remain unreliable per [[WP:UGC]]. [[User:Abayomi2003|Abayomi2003]] ([[User talk:Abayomi2003|talk]]) 18:57, 22 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Katy Perry#rfc_D50F898|Talk:Katy Perry]] expired 2025-04-17 06:01 ===
* Id: D50F898
* User: 207.96.47.51
* Date: 2025-04-14 19:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1285624182|BIO 1285624182}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1286018790|BIO 1286018790}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should leade include Katy Perry as an astronaut? [[Special:Contributions/207.96.47.51|207.96.47.51]] ([[User talk:207.96.47.51|talk]]) 19:11, 14 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Draft talk:Ultrasonic metal atomization#rfc_891D04E|Draft talk:Ultrasonic metal atomization]] expired 2025-04-17 15:01 ===
* Id: 891D04E
* User: Alicja G≈Çaszczka
* Date: 2025-04-17 13:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|1286062028|UNSORTED 1286062028}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|1286069832|UNSORTED 1286069832}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello,

I would like to raise a concern regarding recent edits to this article, particularly in relation to adherence to Wikipedia‚Äôs sourcing guidelines. In the latest revisions, all previously included academic references and scientifically grounded content were removed. Unfortunately, the current version seems to rely heavily on promotional language and lacks the independent, verifiable sources required by Wikipedia.

If an editor wishes to improve or expand the article, the appropriate approach would be to **edit and build upon** the existing content‚Äînot to remove well-sourced scientific information and replace it with content connected to a commercial entity. This approach may violate Wikipedia‚Äôs core principles on [neutral point of view](<nowiki>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view</nowiki>), [verifiability](<nowiki>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability</nowiki>), and [conflict of interest](<nowiki>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Conflict_of_interest</nowiki>).

I suggest we consider restoring the original content supported by academic sources, particularly as references to key sources like the articles and webpages from Warsaw University of Technology have been removed. I also encourage the editor, especially if this is their first edit on Wikipedia, to add the relevant research papers that were originally mentioned.

Thank you! [[User:Alicja G≈Çaszczka|Alicja G≈Çaszczka]] ([[User talk:Alicja G≈Çaszczka|talk]]) 13:39, 17 April 2025 (UTC)}}

[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Newspapers/Notability]]‚Üí [[Wikipedia:Notability (newspapers)]]

Having a guideline for notability of newspapers addresses the challenge of supporting recent increased interest in developing Wikipedia's relationship with fact-checking, journalism, reliable media, and newspapers in particular.

One existing closely related guideline is for books. Here is that, and several comparable essays for media.

*[[Wikipedia:Notability (periodicals)]]
*[[Wikipedia:Notability (academic journals)]]
*[[Wikipedia:Notability of reliable sources]]
*[[Wikipedia:Notability (media)]]

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Weather#rfc_59BC93A|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Weather]] expired 2025-04-21 15:01 ===
* Id: 59BC93A
* User: 216.58.25.209
* Date: 2025-03-22 14:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1281794384|STYLE 1281794384}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1286712330|STYLE 1286712330}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
&#32;
;Part 4 of [[WP:DISASTER]] reads
:If there is no accepted name, the name should be formatted as follows: '''tornado''', '''tornado outbreak''', or '''tornado outbreak sequence''', followed by '''Geographic location''' (only if necessary: City, State, Country, Continent, or any combination of these), followed by '''Year''' (or Month/year, or day/month/year if need be). ''Example: '''[[Tornado outbreak of April 14‚Äì16, 2011]]'''''

Please rank these title options from most to least preferred for a non-[[Tornadoes of 2011|year]] article: {{ordered list |list-style-type=upper-alpha
| Narrow date range
:'''Tornado outbreak of January 2‚Äì3, 1234''' when January 2‚Äì3 covers ~60% of sources
| Broad date range
:'''Tornado outbreak of January 1‚Äì4, 1234''' when January 1‚Äì4 covers ~90% of sources
| Part of month
:'''Tornado outbreak of Early January, 1234''', '''Tornado outbreak of mid-January, 1234''', '''Tornado outbreak of Late January, 1234'''
:Each part is 10 days, moved forward or back 3 days for flexibility and discretion
| Month
:'''Tornado outbreak of January 1234''' }}

The next preferred option is used to [[WP:QUALIFIER|disambiguate]] two events in the same (part of the) month. [[2020‚Äì21 New Year's North American winter storm|Year ranges]] can be used for December‚ÄìJanuary events. This RfC does not change the [[WP:COMMONNAME]] name/location parts [[Wikipedia:Naming_conventions_(events)#Tornadoes_and_tornado_outbreaks|1‚Äì3 of WP:DISASTER]]. [[Special:Contributions/216.58.25.209|216.58.25.209]] ([[User talk:216.58.25.209|talk]]) 14:33, 22 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Abortion#rfc_C4826B5|Talk:Abortion]] expired 2025-04-26 00:01 ===
* Id: C4826B5
* User: DocZach
* Date: 2025-04-06 22:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1284331849|SCI 1284331849}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1284331853|POL 1284331853}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1287397243|SCI 1287397243}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1287397251|POL 1287397251}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''To better align with [[WP:NPOV]], should each section that introduces the term ‚Äúsafe‚Äù or ‚Äúsafety‚Äù in reference to abortion include a brief clarification at first mention‚Äîspecifically, that ‚Äúsafe‚Äù refers to the pregnant woman undergoing the abortion, not the embryo or fetus?'''

For example, take the current first mention of safety in the lead:

''When done legally in industrialized societies, induced abortion is one of the safest procedures in medicine.''

This proposal would adjust that statement to something like:

''When done legally in industrialized societies, induced abortion is one of the safest procedures in medicine for the woman receiving it.''

'''Feel free to vote and comment with one of the following options:'''

* '''Yes, Option A''' ‚Äî The article should clarify, when safety is first addressed in each section, that it is addressing safety for the individual undergoing the abortion.
* '''Yes, Option B''' ‚Äî The article should only clarify it two times: at the first mention of safety in the entire article, and at the first mention of safety in the "Safety" section.
* '''Yes, Option C''' ‚Äî The article should indeed clarify it, but should do so in a footnote.
* '''No''' ‚Äî The article should '''NOT''' clarify whose safety is being discussed.

[[User:DocZach|DocZach]] ([[User talk:DocZach|talk]]) 22:51, 6 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Euthanasia in the United States#rfc_1954860|Talk:Euthanasia in the United States]] expired 2025-04-26 01:01 ===
* Id: 1954860
* User: Helper201
* Date: 2025-03-27 00:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1282537995|SCI 1282537995}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1282537999|POL 1282537999}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1282538005|SOC 1282538005}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1287403065|SCI 1287403065}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1287403066|POL 1287403066}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1287403068|SOC 1287403068}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Firstly, let me set out that I am opening this RFC because similar questions to mine have arisen on this talk page over the years without responses, so I think it is due time to call an RFC, as it would be apparent there would be little if anyone that would respond, given the lack of prior responses on this talk page.

This page is currently very misleading. Assisted suicide and euthanasia are two separate and different things. Euthanasia is ending the life of ''another'' person or animal that is either terminally ill or undergoing unacceptable suffering. Assisted suicide on the other hand one person aiding another in ''taking their own life''. Note: I placed in italics what the key difference is. This distinction is further exemplified by the fact that there is a page called [[Assisted suicide in the United States]]. However, this page uses the term "assisted suicide" multiple times, seemingly conflating euthanasia with assisted suicide, despite the two being distinct and different; therefore, misleading the reader. The whole section for Maine for example only refers to assisted dying, not euthanasia, which this article is about, along with multiple other uses of the term assisted suicide throughout the page.

So where do we go from here? Do we take down the page and put it into draft status until these issues are fixed, or are there people that are willing to run through the page and correct the conflations between assisted suicide and euthanasia and eliminate any use of the former term from this article? I can't say it‚Äôs something I have the time to do personally. [[User:Helper201|Helper201]] ([[User talk:Helper201|talk]]) 00:54, 27 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Suicide methods#rfc_EC31E8E|Talk:Suicide methods]] expired 2025-04-26 03:01 ===
* Id: EC31E8E
* User: Aplucas0703
* Date: 2025-03-27 02:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1282550775|SOC 1282550775}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1287415241|SOC 1287415241}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 A link should be added at the top of the article to [[metawiki:Mental_health_resources|Wikipedia's crisis resources]] in the hatnotes section. [[User:Aplucas0703|aaronneallucas]] ([[User talk:Aplucas0703|talk]]) 02:57, 27 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Trialeti culture#rfc_24D3B77|Talk:Trialeti culture]] expired 2025-04-26 03:01 ===
* Id: 24D3B77
* User: Skeptical1800
* Date: 2025-04-26 00:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1287403073|STYLE 1287403073}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1287415244|STYLE 1287415244}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This culture is called Trialeti-Vanadzor culture, and the name of the page should properly reflect this name. This is how it is primarily referred to in academia, including most/all sources used to cite this page. This page's title should reflect its proper name. Precedence is set for various other cultures in the region, such as Shulaveri-Shomu culture, Kura-Araxes culture, Lchashen-Metsamor culture, etc. [[User:Skeptical1800|Skeptical1800]] ([[User talk:Skeptical1800|talk]]) 00:22, 26 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Illegal immigration to the United States#rfc_1628E57|Talk:Illegal immigration to the United States]] expired 2025-04-26 20:01 ===
* Id: 1628E57
* User: RCraig09
* Date: 2025-03-27 18:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1282647207|POL 1282647207}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1282647210|SOC 1282647210}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1287521691|POL 1287521691}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1287521694|SOC 1287521694}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The narrow question is which term to use in article mainspace: "'''''illegal''''' immigrant" versus "'''''undocumented''''' immigrant". The issue focuses on the adjective applied to the noun ''immigrant''‚Äîthe individual. (This issue is distinguished from using the term "illegal ''immigration''" (the act of immigrating) which is not at issue in this RfC.)

Of course, this RfC does not affect discussion of ''the terms themselves'' in the article. I suggest that editors reply with '''Illegal''' or '''Undocumented''' or other specific adjective. ‚Äî<span style="font-family:Times New Roman;color:dark blue;">[[User:RCraig09|RCraig09]] ([[User talk:RCraig09|talk]])</span> 18:15, 27 March 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Syrian civil war#rfc_2A96A91|Talk:Syrian civil war]] expired 2025-04-28 18:01 ===
* Id: 2A96A91
* User: Meaninglesscharacter
* Date: 2025-04-28 15:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1287807260|POL 1287807260}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1287825281|POL 1287825281}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The Syrian Civil War has been reported as officially over by several major international outlets, such as the New York Times, NPR, The Wall Street Journal, The Guardian, BBC, Reuters, The Financial Times, The Economist, and AP News, among others. Some reports claim that the fall of Assad‚Äôs regime in December 2024 and the formation of a caretaker government mark the end of the civil war. However, other editors feel that there has been insufficient consensus to declare the war officially over.

Here are a few articles that have reported Syria‚Äôs civil war as ended:

[https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/23/world/middleeast/syria-president-al-shara-interview.html Syria‚Äôs Jihadist-Turned-President Seeks New Allies] - The New York Times

‚ÄúThe fear of renewed turmoil in Syria is shared by global powers as the country emerges from a nearly 14-year civil war that sent millions of refugees abroad and enters a new chapter under Mr. al-Shara‚Äôs Islamist government.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt remains unclear what role, if any, Russia will play in postwar Syria. But Mr. al-Shara said Moscow had supplied the Syrian military for decades, implying that his country may need Russia or other nations‚Äô support again in the future.‚Äù

The article is also categorized under ‚ÄúSyria After Civil War‚Äù. 

[https://www.npr.org/2025/04/21/nx-s1-5361048/syria-white-helmets With Assad gone and Syria's war over, the White Helmets have a new mission] - NPR

‚ÄúNow, with Syria's civil war over, the White Helmets are taking on a new challenge: Their founder, Raed Saleh, has been appointed to Syria's Cabinet as minister of emergencies and disaster management, and the force he started 12 years ago is expanding its services ‚Äî for the first time ‚Äî to the entire country.‚Äù

[https://archive.is/2025.04.18-100422/https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/u-s-toughens-demands-on-syrias-new-islamist-led-leadership-695bff58 U.S. Toughens Demands on Syria‚Äôs New Islamist-Led Leadership] - The Wall Street Journal

‚ÄúThe guidance reflects skepticism among administration officials of Syria‚Äôs government, which is led by former rebel commanders who ousted President Bashar al-Assad from power in December, ending the country‚Äôs 13-year-long civil war.‚Äù

[https://www.theguardian.com/news/2025/mar/13/the-reluctant-collaborator-surviving-syrias-brutal-civil-war-and-its-aftermath The reluctant collaborator: surviving Syria‚Äôs brutal civil war ‚Äì and its aftermath] - The Guardian

‚ÄúWhen the forces of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), the Islamist group that led the overthrow of Bashar al-Assad‚Äôs regime, swept into Damascus at the end of the war, they found a city that looked old and exhausted, worn out by years of violence and crippling sanctions, its Ottoman and Mamluk architecture blackened by the fumes of rattling old cars and buses.‚Äù

[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/apr/12/erdogan-lambasts-israel-for-undermining-stability-in-syria Erdoƒüan lambasts Israel for undermining stability in Syria] - The Guardian

‚ÄúAssad‚Äôs overthrow marked the end of over 50 years of dictatorial rule by his family, as well as a halt to a decade-long civil war that became a frozen proxy conflict.‚Äù

[https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cr4nqe3724vo Syrians have more freedom after Assad, but could they lose it?] - BBC

"The interim government is running out of funds, security forces are overstretched, poverty is deepening and insurgency is brewing at the periphery. Outsiders are meddling. Western sanctions deprive leaders of what they need to rebuild, while preventing fragmentation or a return to civil war."

[https://www.ft.com/content/5fe34023-a81f-4f1a-baf5-4059b69121c9 Israel and Turkey begin talks to avoid conflict in Syria] - The Financial Times

‚ÄúTurkey, which long-backed the Syrian opposition, became the main foreign power in Syria after Islamist rebels toppled the regime of Bashar al-Assad in December, ending more than a decade of civil war.‚Äù

[https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/imf-world-bank-meetings-discuss-restoring-support-syria-un-official-says-2025-04-18/ UN development arm plans for $1.3 billion in help for Syria, top official says] - Reuters

‚ÄúAbdallah Dardari told Reuters in Damascus that investing in Syria - hit hard by 14 years of conflict that ended when former leader Bashar al-Assad was ousted by a rebel offensive in December and fled the country - was seen as a "global public good."

‚ÄúSince former Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad was toppled last year after a nearly 14-year civil war, his successors have called on the international community to lift sanctions imposed against the country during his rule.‚Äù

[https://archive.is/2025.03.27-164827/https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2025/03/27/israel-courts-the-middle-easts-minorities Israel courts the Middle East‚Äôs minorities] - The Economist

‚ÄúSome minorities may see benefits in allying with Israel today. Syria is now ruled by a former al-Qaeda leader. A recent massacre of minority Alawites on the country‚Äôs coast has left them crying for protection. Many Syrian manual workers, who are destitute after the civil war, are aware they could earn many times more in Israel.‚Äù

[https://apnews.com/article/syria-landmines-assad-amputations-03f8c5672c9dd943622cd622c8d80b6c ‚ÄòI thought I‚Äôd died.‚Äô How land mines are continuing to claim lives in post-Assad Syria] - AP News

‚ÄúWhile the nearly 14-year Syrian civil war came to an end with the fall of Bashar Assad on Dec. 8, war remnants continue to kill and maim.‚Äù

We are seeking input on the following:
1. Do you think the Syrian Civil War has officially ended, based on the sources provided?
2. Should the Wikipedia article reflect this, and if so, how should this be worded?

The discussion on this issue has been ongoing for several months without reaching a resolution, so we are now seeking broader input from the community.

--[[User:Meaninglesscharacter|Meaninglesscharacter]] ([[User talk:Meaninglesscharacter|talk]]) 15:53, 28 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Inah Canabarro Lucas#rfc_D4BAED1|Talk:Inah Canabarro Lucas]] expired 2025-05-01 21:01 ===
* Id: D4BAED1
* Date: 2025-04-24 02:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1287116208|BIO 1287116208}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1287116210|STYLE 1287116210}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1288314140|BIO 1288314140}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1288314145|STYLE 1288314145}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the infobox for Inah Canabarro Lucas include things like "oldest living nun", "oldest living person in South America", and "oldest living person in Latin America", or should those be moved to the article body?
These claims are accurate, but they don‚Äôt seem to get much attention in reliable sources. The subject is mainly known for being the oldest living person in the world. Per [[WP:DUE]] and [[WP:RS]], should the infobox focus only on what‚Äôs most notable and widely covered?
For example, Lucile Randon was the oldest nun ever, but even her infobox didn‚Äôt list ‚Äúnun‚Äù as something she was known for. Should we treat these extra titles the same way and keep them out of the infobox?
[[User:Avengingbandit|<span style="background:#008080;border-top:solid lime 2px;border-right:solid blue 2px;border-bottom:solid blue 2px;border-left:solid lime 2px;color:cyan">'''''Avengingbandit'''''</span>]] 02:41, 24 April 2025 (UTC)}}

I've been asking this for quite some time already, but I think i should ask again:

Can Chinese ship emblems be uploaded? Currently, to avoid any issues I just add an external media template.

But seeing how military insignia fall under the PRC copyright law's article 5(" laws and regulations, resolutions, decisions and orders of State organs, other documents of a legislative, administrative or judicial nature and the official translations thereof;"), may I ask again if navy ship emblems can be uploaded or at least given non free fair use? === [[Talk:Jeffersonian democracy#rfc_24BFC09|Talk:Jeffersonian democracy]] expired 2025-05-02 19:01 ===
* Id: 24BFC09
* User: GlowstoneUnknown
* Date: 2025-04-14 08:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1285543927|POL 1285543927}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1288454033|POL 1288454033}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This page has been using [[Template:Infobox political party]] for several years at this point (since [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jeffersonian_democracy&direction=next&oldid=961115037 5 September 2020]), and I'd like to make the case that this infobox should either be removed, replaced, or greatly overhauled. It's not helpful to portray individual ideologies as if they were organised political parties with their own ideologies and it seems like the infobox on this page (as well as on pages such as [[Anti-Federalism]]) is causing repeated content disputes.

On top of that, almost none of the currently-utilised parameters in the infobox are appropriate:


"Ideology" ‚Äî Jeffersonian democracy is ''itself'' an ideology, or at the very least an ideological movement.

"Dissolved" ‚Äî How can an ideology or a political philosophy be dissolved?

"Colors" ‚Äî Ideologies can't have colors.

"Historical leaders" ‚Äî Again, this isn't a party, there can't therefore be a leader.

"Merged into" ‚Äî As Jeffersonian democracy wasn't an organised party, there's no entity to merge into anything.


Options: '''Remove''' or '''Keep''' (referring to the infobox) <span style="text-shadow:5px 5px 25px Black;font-family:Courier;font-weight:bold;font-size:110%">[[User:GlowstoneUnknown|<span style="color:#f44">‚Äì GlowstoneUnknown</span>]] [[User talk:GlowstoneUnknown|<span style="color:#f9f">(Talk)</span>]]</span> 08:28, 14 April 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Help talk:IPA/Standard German#rfc_7231167|Help talk:IPA/Standard German]] expired 2025-05-03 12:01 ===
* Id: 7231167
* User: Sol505000
* Date: 2025-04-03 11:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1283894915|LANG 1283894915}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1288553767|LANG 1288553767}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should add the voiceless diacritics underneath/above the lenes, as in {{angbr IPA|bÃ• dÃ• …°Ãä}} for transcriptions involving Swiss and Austrian Standard German? Even though the word- and morpheme-final orthographic {{angbr|b d g}} aren't fortified, they aren't voiced either and the bare symbols {{angbr IPA|b d …°}} might be ''more'' confusing than {{angbr IPA|p t k}} (used previously, in alignment with pronunciation dictionaries) by the official IPA standards, not less. {{IPA|[Ààhabsb är…°]}} doesn't feature a voiced-voiceless-voiced sequence in the middle, nor is the final sound voiced.

There's also a question of {{IPA|[bÃ•vÃ• dÃ•zÃ• dÃ• íÃä vÃ• zÃ•  íÃä …£Ãä]}} - are they in any way relevant in the southern standards? Any important allophonies we should transcribe? Then, what about {{IPA|[ ùÃä]}}? Does that exist?

And should we then switch to transcribing the voiced labiodental with {{angbr IPA| ã}} as far as the southern varieties are concerned? [[User:Sol505000|Sol505000]] ([[User talk:Sol505000|talk]]) 11:16, 3 April 2025 (UTC)}}
