=== [[Talk:2023 Jacksonville shooting#rfc_5AB1BB2|Talk:2023 Jacksonville shooting]] expired 2025-10-18 22:01 ===
* Id: 5AB1BB2
* User: Raskuly
* Date: 2025-10-15 21:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1317025296|POL 1317025296}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1317025301|SOC 1317025301}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1317590161|POL 1317590161}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1317590163|SOC 1317590163}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What should be the parameters for determining what a mass shooting is on Wikipedia for the purpose of categorization?
*'''A''' - Three or more shot, excluding the perpetrators, in one incident at one location at roughly the same time per [https://stanfordmag.org/contents/geospatial-center-tracks-mass-shootings Stanford University]'s MSA data project
*'''B''' - Four or more shot, excluding the perpetrators, in one incident in one location at roughly the same time per [https://www.gunviolencearchive.org/methodology Gun Violence Archive]
*'''C''' - Four or more shot and killed, excluding the perpetrators, in one incident at one location at roughly the same time per [https://www.theviolenceproject.org/mass-shooter-database/ Violence Prevention Project]
*'''D''' - Three or more shot and killed, excluding the perpetrators, in one incident at a public place, excluding all shootings the organization considers to be "conventionally motivated," such as all gang violence and armed robberies per ''[https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/12/mass-shootings-mother-jones-full-data/ Mother Jones]''
*'''E''' - Four or more shot and killed, excluding the perpetrators, in one incident at a public place per ''[https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/interactive/mass-shootings/ The Washington Post]''
*'''F''' - Four or more shot and killed, excluding the perpetrators, in one incident at a public place, excluding gang-related killings and those done with a profit motive per the [https://www.congress.gov/crs-product/R43004 Congressional Research Service]
[[User:Raskuly|Raskuly]] ([[User talk:Raskuly|talk]]) 21:34, 15 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tet Offensive#rfc_993F674|Talk:Tet Offensive]] expired 2025-10-22 07:01 ===
* Id: 993F674
* User: Summerhall fire
* Date: 2025-09-22 06:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1312728071|HIST 1312728071}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318157339|HIST 1318157339}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I recently changed the Outcomes Section from the "Viet Cong suffered catastrophic losses... etc." 

To "Viet Cong suffered significant losses... etc" 

A user reverted the change below. 

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tet_Offensive&diff=prev&oldid=1312724376

A user had reverted the change, but did not attempt to reconcile the different positions in the last thread. The previous outcome description had no clear evidence or references, and clear contradictions since neither the Viet Cong nor its method of insurgency was destroyed by the Tet Offensive as these results implied. This is inserting a POV perspective which contradicts historical records. 

Reference for the basis for these changes is found below:

"At the end of 1967, approximately 225,000 Viet Cong and PAVN forces were in the south. Despite casualties taken, Viet Cong and PAVN forces numbered 251,000 by the end of 1968. The Tet Offensive had little impact on troop numbers, and the Viet Cong remained a viable fighting force until the end of the war.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Villard |first=Erik |date=2021-03-13 |title=A Controversial Question: Did Tet Decimate the Viet Cong? |url=https://www.historynet.com/villard-tet/ |access-date=2025-09-21 |website=HistoryNet |language=en-US}}</ref>" 



[[User:Summerhall fire|Summerhall fire]] ([[User talk:Summerhall fire|talk]]) 06:38, 22 September 2025 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1318138967|POLICY 1318138967}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1323351997|POLICY 1323351997}}
=== [[Wikipedia talk:Protection policy#rfc_5F63857|Wikipedia talk:Protection policy]] expired 2025-10-22 21:01 ===
* Id: 5F63857
* User: Daniel Quinlan
* Date: 2025-09-22 20:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1312838357|POLICY 1312838357}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1312838359|TECH 1312838359}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1318257088|POLICY 1318257088}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1318257091|TECH 1318257091}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Background:
* The main issue with extended confirmed protection (ECP) is that it's trivial to run up edit counts to 500 edits very quickly. Even though most extreme gaming is detected relatively quickly in several different ways, just a few minutes is long enough to seriously disrupt ECP articles, and some accounts slip through even with the new measures we have in place.
* Full protection is not a good solution for this because it prevents editing to important articles and vandals gaming ECP will shift to other pages when their target is fully protected (as happened while [[Donald Trump]] was fully protected).
Revised proposal:
* Update the site configuration so the <code>autoconfirmed</code> group is required before an account is granted <code>extendedconfirmed</code>. It's a small modification to the <code>wmgAutopromoteOnceonEdit</code> setting (see the [https://noc.wikimedia.org/wiki.php enwiki settings]).
* We allow several high accuracy edit filters to revoke autoconfirmed. This is already supported natively. The edit filter managers would also update [[MediaWiki:Abusefilter-degrouped]] to be more general and less accusatory.
* Remove <code>blockautopromote</code> from <code>wgAbuseFilterActionRestrictions</code> so the <code>blockautopromote</code> action won't be disabled when the filters have a high rate of matches (which already happens because ECP gaming happens at a high rate). This will also allow non-administrator EFMs to edit these abuse filters (they can already restore autoconfirmed when a filter removes it so this is not a big deal).
This will help address the biggest problem we have right now with ECP: the 5-30 minute delay between ECP being granted and an administrator at AIV acting on an automated report from one of several edit filters. [[User:Daniel Quinlan|Daniel Quinlan]] ([[User talk:Daniel Quinlan|talk]]) 20:47, 22 September 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bee Gees#rfc_57F0913|Talk:Bee Gees]] expired 2025-10-23 02:01 ===
* Id: 57F0913
* User: ImprovedWikiImprovment
* Date: 2025-09-23 01:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1312860592|MEDIA 1312860592}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1318297172|MEDIA 1318297172}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we state "[[Redcliffe, Queensland]], Australia (or maybe a different specific place in QLD) as this band's origin, since the adoption of the name taking place there per article sources? Or should we state [[Manchester]], England per the inital founding place of [[The Rattlesnakes (1950s band)]]? My view is this was a seperate band, with the Bee Gees being formed in Queensland.

Due to a history of edit warring, I feel an RfC is necessary for community input. It makes sense to leave the field blank if no consensus has been reached yet, but I hope this RfC will resolve it. Of course no individual editor is in a position at this time to fill the field, in my view. --[[User:ImprovedWikiImprovment|IWI]] ([[User talk:ImprovedWikiImprovment|talk]]) 01:13, 23 September 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:C (programming language)#rfc_579B7F4|Talk:C (programming language)]] expired 2025-10-24 01:01 ===
* Id: 579B7F4
* User: 24.50.56.74
* Date: 2025-10-20 18:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1317904945|SCI 1317904945}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1318463326|SCI 1318463326}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am requesting comments to move the opening bracket ('{{mono|{}}') from a newline to the same line as the signature. My reasoning is to cite this:<ref name="ctut">{{cite web |url=https://www.bell-labs.com/usr/dmr/www/ctut.pdf |title=Programming in C: A Tutorial |last1=Kernighan |first1=Brian |author1-link=Brian Kernighan |year=1974 |publisher=Bell Labs |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220322215231/https://www.bell-labs.com/usr/dmr/www/ctut.pdf |archive-date=22 March 2022 |access-date=9 January 2019}}</ref> This is cited in the page [["Hello, World!" program]] which provides a Hello, world program in C cited from the K&R book. If approved I will apply this change to both the original "Hello, world" program and the more modern version.

Please provide comments and thoughts. [[Special:Contributions/24.50.56.74|24.50.56.74]] ([[User talk:24.50.56.74|talk]]) 18:34, 20 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_12B3A53|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2025-10-24 03:01 ===
* Id: 12B3A53
* User: Chetsford
* Date: 2025-10-24 00:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1318456798|SOC 1318456798}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1323642150|SOC 1323642150}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Q1:''' In regards to paranormal topics (including UFOs and adjacent, mainstream subjects such as astronomy, politics, and aerospace engineering), is Nick Pope ...
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting.
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply.
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting.
*'''Option 4:''' Other (individual authors are unfilterable so no deprecation option is offered)

'''Q2:''' If this RfC results in a decipherable outcome, how should it be logged at [[WP:RSP]]? 
*'''Option 1:''' An independent entry for Nick Pope. 
*'''Option 2:''' A single entry for "UFO content creators" or "paranormal content creators" which could be populated with other names if similarly decided in the future. 
*'''Option 3:''' No record should be preserved of this RfC outside of the noticeboard archives. 
*'''Option 4:''' Other
[[User:Chetsford|Chetsford]] ([[User talk:Chetsford|talk]]) 00:00, 24 October 2025 (UTC)}}
There has been ongoing disagreement about whether to include the following line in the article:

:''‚ÄúAs of May 2025, no bodies have been confirmed at the suspected gravesites of the Kamloops residential school.‚Äù''
This sentence is currently supported by multiple reliable sources, including ''The New York Times'' (2024), ''Vancouver Is Awesome'' (2024), and the Indian Residential School Research Group (2023):<ref>{{Cite news |date=2024-09-20 |title=What Lies Beneath Canada‚Äôs Former Indigenous School Sites Fuels a Debate (Published 2024) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/20/canada-indigenous-schools-unmarked-graves.html |website=[[The New York Times]]|last=Austen|first=Ian|access-date=2025-10-12 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Wood |first=Graeme |date=September 25, 2024 |title=B.C. lawyers keep language on Kamloops residential school discovery |url=https://www.vancouverisawesome.com/highlights/bc-lawyers-keep-language-on-kamloops-residential-school-discovery-9568030 |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=Vancouver Is Awesome |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Rouillard |first=Jacques |date=2023-06-22 |title=In Kamloops, Not One Body Has Been Found |url=https://irsrg.ca/articles/in-kamloops-not-one-body-has-been-found/ |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=IRSRG |language=en-US}}</ref>
'''Full section in context:'''
:In February 2025, Brodie posted a statement on [[Twitter|X]] that read in part: "The number of confirmed child burials at the former [[Kamloops Indian Residential School]] site is zero. Zero. No one should be afraid of the truth. Not lawyers, their governing bodies, or anyone else." '''As of May 2025, no bodies have been confirmed at the suspected gravesites of the Kamloops residential school.'''[1][2][3] The [[Union of British Columbia Indian Chiefs]] called for Brodie to apologize as she perpetuated Residential School Denialism. Conservative House Leader [[√Å ºaÍûâl√≠ya Warbus]] criticized the post as harmful and a distraction for the party from more important issues. Rustad asked Brodie to take down the post, which she refused to do. The same day as Rustad made his request, Brodie was one of five Conservative MLAs to vote against a motion condemning the [[2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico|tariff threats of American president Donald Trump]] and supporting retaliatory tariffs if necessary.
'''Dispute:'''
Some editors have repeatedly removed this line, disagreeing with the contents as denialism and cherrypicked. Others have argued that it reflects verifiable, current information that adds important factual context and is supported by reliable sources.  
'''Question:'''  
Should this line '''remain''' in the article, be '''removed''' entirely, or be '''rewritten''' in another form?
Please provide reasoning with reference to relevant policies such as [[WP:NPOV]], [[WP:RS]], [[WP:UNDUE]], and [[WP:CONSENSUS]].  
'''[[User:TimeToFixThis|<span style="color:black;">TimeToFixThis</span>]]''' &#x7c; [[User talk:TimeToFixThis|üïí]] 01:28, 14 October 2025 (UTC)}}

There has been ongoing disagreement about whether to include the following line in the article:

:''‚ÄúAs of May 2025, no bodies have been confirmed at the suspected gravesites of the Kamloops residential school.‚Äù''

This sentence is currently supported by multiple reliable sources, including ''The New York Times'' (2024), ''Vancouver Is Awesome'' (2024), and the Indian Residential School Research Group (2023):<ref>{{Cite news |date=2024-09-20 |title=What Lies Beneath Canada‚Äôs Former Indigenous School Sites Fuels a Debate (Published 2024) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/20/canada-indigenous-schools-unmarked-graves.html |website=[[The New York Times]]|last=Austen|first=Ian|access-date=2025-10-12 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Wood |first=Graeme |date=September 25, 2024 |title=B.C. lawyers keep language on Kamloops residential school discovery |url=https://www.vancouverisawesome.com/highlights/bc-lawyers-keep-language-on-kamloops-residential-school-discovery-9568030 |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=Vancouver Is Awesome |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Rouillard |first=Jacques |date=2023-06-22 |title=In Kamloops, Not One Body Has Been Found |url=https://irsrg.ca/articles/in-kamloops-not-one-body-has-been-found/ |access-date=2025-10-12 |website=IRSRG |language=en-US}}</ref>

'''Full section in context:'''
:In February 2025, Brodie posted a statement on [[Twitter|X]] that read in part: "The number of confirmed child burials at the former [[Kamloops Indian Residential School]] site is zero. Zero. No one should be afraid of the truth. Not lawyers, their governing bodies, or anyone else." '''As of May 2025, no bodies have been confirmed at the suspected gravesites of the Kamloops residential school.'''[1][2][3] The [[Union of British Columbia Indian Chiefs]] called for Brodie to apologize as she perpetuated Residential School Denialism. Conservative House Leader [[√Å ºaÍûâl√≠ya Warbus]] criticized the post as harmful and a distraction for the party from more important issues. Rustad asked Brodie to take down the post, which she refused to do. The same day as Rustad made his request, Brodie was one of five Conservative MLAs to vote against a motion condemning the [[2025 United States trade war with Canada and Mexico|tariff threats of American president Donald Trump]] and supporting retaliatory tariffs if necessary.

'''Dispute:'''
Some editors have repeatedly removed this line, disagreeing with the contents as denialism and cherrypicked. Others have argued that it reflects verifiable, current information that adds important factual context and is supported by reliable sources.  

'''Question:'''  
Should this line '''remain''' in the article, be '''removed''' entirely, or be '''rewritten''' in another form?

Please provide reasoning with reference to relevant policies such as [[WP:NPOV]], [[WP:RS]], [[WP:UNDUE]], and [[WP:CONSENSUS]].

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Baltic states-related articles#rfc_64E2EC6|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Baltic states-related articles]] expired 2025-10-26 00:01 ===
* Id: 64E2EC6
* User: User:Glebushko0703
* Date: 2025-10-25 02:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318637798|HIST 1318637798}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1318637803|POL 1318637803}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1318637807|STYLE 1318637807}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318911021|HIST 1318911021}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1318911024|POL 1318911024}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the biographic infobox [[Template:Infobox_person #birth_place|birthplaces]] of people born in [[Lithuania]], [[Latvia]], or [[Estonia]], in 1940‚Äì1941 or 1944‚Äì1991 (when they were controlled by the former [[USSR]]) not mention, or specifically mention in some detail, that these territories were then annexed by the USSR?   For example: [Kaja Kallas] Born 18 June 1977 (age 48) in:

A) Tallinn, Estonian SSR, Soviet Union;

B) Tallinn, Estonian SSR, Soviet Union (now Estonia);

C) Tallinn, Estonia.

Please focus on reaching a consensus since this debate is  old and causes confusion among editors disolving the common format.

[[Special:Contributions/User:Glebushko0703|Gigman]] ([[User:Glebushko0703|talk]]) 02:18, 25 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Browser engine#rfc_374B674|Talk:Browser engine]] expired 2025-10-26 03:01 ===
* Id: 374B674
* User: Niranjan Ramamurthy
* Date: 2025-10-23 22:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1318450556|TECH 1318450556}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1318805031|TECH 1318805031}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Dear editors,

I am opening this rfc to propose the inclusion of a new section in the article. The goal is to provide non-technical readers with a fuller picture of recent developments in the browser engine landscape, including market consolidation and the emergence of independent engines.

Currently, the article is a concise technical summary. However, the most significant story in 2025 concerns the dominance of Google‚Äôs Blink engine‚Äîoften called the ‚ÄúBlink monoculture‚Äù‚Äîand the related U.S. antitrust case. Leaving this out risks presenting an incomplete view.

I propose adding a new section, ‚ÄúMarket Consolidation and Independent Development,‚Äù immediately after Notable engines. This order is logical: first readers see the engines, then the real-world context in which they operate. [[User:Niranjan Ramamurthy|Niranjan Ramamurthy]] ([[User talk:Niranjan Ramamurthy|talk]]) 22:38, 23 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:History of Anatolia#rfc_6F67D70|Talk:History of Anatolia]] expired 2025-10-26 12:01 ===
* Id: 6F67D70

* Date: 2025-10-25 00:42:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318854629|HIST 1318854629}}

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Options''' 

1. Add modern history including Ottoman era, Ottoman collapse, modern Turkey, etc. Some of this is in a list at the end, but this needs some dates added to be a more useful overview.

2. Give the page a more precise name and put the pages that cover modern history in easy to find places at both the top and bottom of the page.

[[Special:Contributions/2405:6E00:62F:3C77:D904:ED5:248C:FE9F|2405:6E00:62F:3C77:D904:ED5:248C:FE9F]] ([[User talk:2405:6E00:62F:3C77:D904:ED5:248C:FE9F|talk]]) 00:42, 25 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Portuguese Nagasaki#rfc_7E49371|Talk:Portuguese Nagasaki]] expired 2025-10-26 14:01 ===
* Id: 7E49371
* User: Kolno
* Date: 2025-10-25 13:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318704664|HIST 1318704664}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318869288|HIST 1318869288}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This follows up on my earlier post above. The infobox and some wording in the article give the impression that Nagasaki was a Portuguese colony. However, according to John Whitney Hall (The Cambridge History of Japan, Vol. 4, p. 330):

"But Nagasaki, contrary to what is sometimes asserted, never became a Portuguese colony. Instead, it was for a few years a Jesuit colony."

Should the article be updated? [[User:Kolno|Kolno]] ([[User talk:Kolno|talk]]) 13:37, 25 October 2025 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1318911024|POL 1318911024}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1318911027|STYLE 1318911027}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1318935038|HIST 1318935038}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1318935045|POL 1318935045}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1318935051|STYLE 1318935051}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the period of Soviet (and Nazi) rule over the three countries from 1940 to 1991 be reflected in the use of e.g [[Estonian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] (or [[Reichskomissariat Ostland]], [[Nazi Germany]]) to describe birth and death places in the Baltics, or should simply Estonia (Latvia, Lithuania) be used?  For example: [[Kaja Kallas]], Born 18 June 1977 (age 48) in ...<br>

<small>'''A''' ...</small> [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]]<br>

<small>'''A1''' ...</small> [[Tallinn]], Estonia<ref name="Europarliament"><small>[[Estonia]] was occupied and annexed by the [[USSR]] at the time. See, for instance, the position expressed in 1983 by the [[European Parliament]], which condemned "the fact that the occupation of these formerly independent and neutral States by the Soviet Union occurred in 1940 following the Molotov‚ÄìRibbentrop pact, and continues". {{cite journal |last=European Parliament |date=13 January 1983 |title=Resolution on the situation in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania |url=http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/80/Europarliament13011983.jpg |journal=Official Journal of the European Communities |volume=C 42/78}}</small></ref> <br> 

<small>'''B''' ...</small> [[Tallinn]], Estonia (then [[Estonian SSR|annexed]] by [[USSR]])<ref name="Europarliament" /> <br>

<small>'''C''' ...</small> [[Tallinn]] (then [[Estonian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]]) <br>

<small>'''D''' ...</small> [[Tallinn]], [[Estonian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]]

<small>As can be seen above, on this Talk page of [[Kaja Kallas]], in [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Baltic states-related articles]] and elsewhere, the previous discussions have not come even close to consensus, instead the "votes" tend to split between "extremes" around '''A''' and '''D'''. Hopefully, finding the "middle ground" could be easier around the new options '''A1''', '''B''', or '''C''' (with added footnote and/or parentheses).<br>  

I will not be participating in the discussion. Please note that for many people the words "Nazi", "Soviet" and "occupied" have almost no geographic meaning, however (by strong association with Hitler, Stalin, their crimes, World War II) using them in biographies is inevitably going to seem offensive for many, and be very offensive for some people. Please try to be less offensive, and to not feel (unnecessarily) more offended yourselves. Good luck!</small> [[User:IdrapoelIII|IdrapoelIII]] ([[User talk:IdrapoelIII|talk]]) 18:11, 26 October 2025 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Ignore all rules#rfc_70BFA72|Wikipedia talk:Ignore all rules]] expired 2025-10-26 22:01 ===
* Id: 70BFA72
* User: Gordon Maximo
* Date: 2025-10-25 09:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1318678946|POLICY 1318678946}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1318935056|POLICY 1318935056}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose to add the following to the IAR policy:

{{quote|The purpose of this policy is improvement of Wikipedia, so if an editor planning to invoke it has reasonable grounds to believe their action will be controversial, they should establish a prior [[WP:CON|consensus]].}}

To be clear, I propose this as an addition to the policy wording, rather than a footnote or guidance. If deemed necessary, a footnote or guidance can clarify that "improvement" and "controversial" are meant in the way that established and experienced Wikipedians would understand them, not their plain meaning. [[User:Gordon Maximo|Gordon Maximo]] ([[User talk:Gordon Maximo|talk]]) 09:40, 25 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:S√©bastien Lecornu#rfc_E99D118|Talk:S√©bastien Lecornu]] expired 2025-10-27 20:01 ===

{{rfcquote|text=
S√©bastien Lecornu resigned as prime minister of 6 October 2025 and served as a caretaker prime minister until a successor could be appointed. However, 4 days later, President Macron reappointed him prime minister.

Because Lecornu hasn't served as prime minister in full capacity since 6 September 2025, some users have been debating the formatting of the infobox. Should he have a note by the term start date? Should there be an underlining mention that he served as a caretaker during the 4 days? Or should there be nothing there at all?

Which option of infobox should we use for this page '''Option A''', '''Option B''', or '''Option C'''? See the three options in infobox form below. '''[[User:TimeToFixThis|<span style="color:black;">TimeToFixThis</span>]]''' &#x7c; [[User talk:TimeToFixThis|üïí]] 01:31, 17 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Factitious disorder imposed on another#rfc_6C1FF84|Talk:Factitious disorder imposed on another]] expired 2025-10-28 19:01 ===
* Id: 6C1FF84
* User: ThouShaltEdit
* Date: 2025-10-28 17:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1319252756|BIO 1319252756}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1319252762|POLICY 1319252762}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1319260914|BIO 1319260914}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1319260923|POLICY 1319260923}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
</nowiki>  

<!-- [[User:DoNotArchiveUntil]] 18:01, 2 December 2025 (UTC) -->{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1764698485}}
policy{{!}}bio{{!}}medicine}}

Wikipedia's role is to summarize what high-quality sources verify, not to adjudicate or amplify unverified abuse narratives. Labeling a deceased person with Factitious Disorder Imposed on Another (FDIA/MBP) necessarily labels the living relative as that person's "victim,' and now indirectly affects a minor child. 

Because these are biomedical and psychiatric assertions, WP:MEDRS applies; because they involve identifiable persons, WP:BLP and WP:BDP require heightened caution. Per WP:V and WP:ONUS, if sourcing cannot meet MEDRS-compliant standards, the material should be omitted. 

Editors should also consider WP:NOTADVOCACY, ensuring the article does not become a vehicle for advocacy or image-shaping, and WP:MINORS, which requires special care when coverage could impact a child. WP:COI is a separate matter, but regardless of who proposes or objects to text, inclusion must satisfy these policy thresholds.

Wikipedia must not function as an evidence vector in real-world legal, family court, or CPS contexts by repeating unverified psychiatric or biomedical accusations as fact.

Question for consensus: Should biomedical or psychiatric claims (for example, FDIA/MBP diagnoses) attributed to or applied to deceased individuals meet MEDRS-level sourcing, given their direct implications for identifiable living persons?

[[User:ThouShaltEdit|ThouShaltEdit]] ([[User talk:ThouShaltEdit|talk]]) 17:57, 28 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:AfriForum#rfc_29F2AA1|Talk:AfriForum]] expired 2025-10-29 15:01 ===
* Id: 29F2AA1
* User: Nib2905
* Date: 2025-09-29 14:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1314066846|POL 1314066846}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1319393221|POL 1319393221}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Afriforum describes itself as a non-governmental organisation, which has the self stated purpose of "to call up Afrikaners to participate in public debate and actions outside of the sphere of party politics."[https://afriforum.co.za/en/about-us/] In 2014 Afriforum described itself as a "South African civil rights organisation focusing on minority rights (and especially Afrikaner rights).¬† [Afriforum] aims to activate the South African civil society to participate positively in the promotion and protection of minority rights outside the realm of party politics. " [https://www.ohchr.org/sites/default/files/Documents/HRBodies/HRCouncil/MinorityIssues/Session7/Item4/Participants/AfriForum.docx]

It has been argued by everday South Africans that Afriforum is a white supremacist organisation with an alternative purpose.[https://iol.co.za/news/politics/2025-02-04-netizens-want-dangerous-grifters-afriforum-to-be-labelled-a-white-supremacist-group-after-trumps-land-confiscation-claims/] The journalist Pieter du Toit has argued that Afriforum is an Afrikaner Nationalist group (specifically he called them an "emissary of a new form of Afrikaner nationalism". The founders of Afriforum have been accused of aiming to build a "Volkstaat" (a white homeland for Afrikaners within South Africa).[https://thoughtleader.co.za/afriforum-and-the-rise-of-the-new-right/] Afriforum has been called a racist lobby group.[https://www.okayafrica.com/afriforumcivil-rights-organisation-or-racist-lobby-group/178278] In general their description as an organization, and their purpose as an organisation is highly contestable.[https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2025/3/24/from-south-africa-to-the-us-white-victimhood-knows-no-borders][https://www.anc1912.org.za/afriforums-racist-agenda-fuels-misinformation-on-south-africas-land-reform/]

Should we define Afriforum as a non-governmental organisation with its self-stated purpose and place criticisms of this description later in the lead, or should we describe them differently (whether white supremacist, afrikaner nationalist ect), with a different purpose at the start of the lead. If we describe them differently, how?  [[User:Nib2905|Nib2905]] ([[User talk:Nib2905|talk]]) 14:09, 29 September 2025 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a dispute about whether brackets inserted in a quotation interfere with readability. Which of these versions of the quotation is most appropriate:

*'''A''' (without brackets): She met and started dating actor Michael Cera when they were filming ''Scott Pilgrim vs. the World''; during their 18-month relationship, Plaza and Cera almost got married as a joke while driving through Las Vegas. Cera explained that "the idea was to then get a divorce right away, so we could call each other "my ex-husband" and "my ex-wife" at like ‚Ä¶ 20."
*'''B''' (with brackets). She met and started dating actor Michael Cera when they were filming ''Scott Pilgrim vs. the World''; during their 18-month relationship, Plaza and Cera almost got married as a joke while driving through Las Vegas. Cera explained that "the idea was to then get a divorce right away, so we could call each other 'my ex-husband' and 'my ex-wife' at like[,] 20 [years old]."

=== [[Talk:Jain sculpture#rfc_41630F2|Talk:Jain sculpture]] expired 2025-10-30 09:01 ===
* Id: 41630F2
* User: ENcrash
* Date: 2025-10-29 18:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1319423979|HIST 1319423979}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1322134213|HIST 1322134213}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Requesting input from editors knowledgeable in Buddhist and South Asian art:
{{WikiProject Buddhism}}
{{WikiProject South Asia}}
{{WikiProject Art}}


Hello,  
I would like to request a neutral community discussion regarding the identification of the statue currently described as a Jain image in this article. Upon close iconographic review, the statue displays multiple key characteristics commonly associated with **PƒÅla-period Buddha sculptures**, such as:

- A clearly defined **u·π£·πáƒ´·π£a** (cranial bump)
- A possible **≈´r·πáƒÅ** (dot between eyebrows, currently obscured by a red jewel)
- **Curly hair pattern**
- **Two bodhisattva-like attendants** beside the central figure
- **Lion-shaped throne base**, symbolically linked to ≈öƒÅkyamuni ("Lion of the ≈öƒÅkyas")
- Narrative reliefs above and around the figure depicting scenes consistent with the **Buddha‚Äôs early life or JƒÅtaka tales**

For comparative reference, please see:

- [Bonhams: A Blackstone Stele of Buddha, PƒÅla Period (10th century)](https://www.bonhams.com/auction/24777/lot/22/a-blackstone-stele-of-buddha-northeastern-india-pala-period-circa-10th-century/)
- [Zacke: A BLACK STONE STELE DEPICTING BUDDHA, PALA EMPIRE] (https://www.zacke.at/auction/lot/lot-200---a-black-stone-stele-depicting-buddha-pala-empire/?lot=34650&sd=1)
- [Wikipedia: U·π£·πáƒ´·π£a](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ushnisha)
- [Wikipedia: ≈™r·πáƒÅ (Buddhism)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urna_(Buddhism))
- [Wikimedia commons: Seated Buddha, East India, Pala, 10th-11th century AD] (https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Seated_Buddha,_East_India,_Pala,_10th-11th_century_AD,_basalt_-_Matsuoka_Museum_of_Art_-_Tokyo,_Japan_-_DSC07189.JPG)
- [Wikipedia: Sultanganj Buddha] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sultanganj_Buddha)
- [Pinterest: Buddha Shakyamuni. India, Bihar; Pala period (c.8th - 12th century), late 9th - early 10th century] (https://in.pinterest.com/pin/378443174923060096/)

I believe a neutral review by multiple editors could help clarify whether this statue‚Äôs description as "Jain" accurately reflects its iconography and historical context, or whether the identification might require revision to reflect Buddhist artistic traits.

Thank you for your time and input. [[User:ENcrash|ENcrash]] ([[User talk:ENcrash|talk]]) 18:54, 29 October 2025 (UTC)}}

Should [[WP:CSD U5|CSD U5]] be 1) repealed and replaced with a combination of 2) procedural deletion of non-contributors' user subpages after six months of no edits, 3) a narrower criterion for off-topic content that has escaped deletion under (2), 4) formalizing the practice of moving drafts off of top-level userpages, and 5) allowing editors to blank userpages that would be eligible for speedy deletion under (3) if they were subpages? <span style="font-family:courier"> -- [[User:Tamzin|<span style="color:#E6007A">Tamzin</span>]]</span><sup class="nowrap">&#91;[[User talk:Tamzin|<i style="color:#E6007A">cetacean needed</i>]]]</sup> <small>([[User:Tamzin/ü§∑|they&#124;xe&#124;ü§∑]])</small> 10:59, 30 September 2025 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Wikipedia recognizes that there is a

that the [[Gaza genocide]] is ongoing, and is caused by Israel. Therefore, Wikipedia states that a genocide is ongoing in wikivoice. === [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_52D08D7|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2025-10-31 16:01 ===
* Id: 52D08D7
* Date: 2025-10-03 14:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1314854531|POLICY 1314854531}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1314854533|TECH 1314854533}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1319741808|POLICY 1319741808}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1319741813|TECH 1319741813}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Background, currently, we block all [[WP:Tor]] exit nodes such that any user wanting to edit through a Tor exit node would first need to contact a administrator and obtain the [[WP:IPBE]] user right before making any edits. (i.e. convince a admin that you will edit constructively and not sock, which is a much higher bar than typical autoconfirmed). However, currently MediaWiki artificially extends the period of time a user needs to edit for to be autoconfirmed to be atleast 90 day with a edit threshold of 100 edits. This is enforced by the the [[mw:Extension:TorBlock|TorBlock extension]] which was added [https://gerrit.wikimedia.org/r/plugins/gitiles/mediawiki/extensions/TorBlock/+/2e449d91247042e187442bd45671e3d26a5180ca some time in 2008]. Since then, our policies have shifted, in the current day, due to our [[m:No open proxies|No open proxies]] rules, editing through Tor exit nodes are typically always blocked locally (and many times globally). Due to this, the bar for editing through Tor proxies has become "request the IPBE userright" + the aformentioned extended autoconfirmed userright. Given this, I would like to propose that we remove the special extended time period to get autoconfirmed for Tor users, and instead equalize the bar for recieving the autconfirmed userright for both Tor and non-Tor users. -- 14:56, 3 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2025 Nepalese Gen Z protests#rfc_4E263FB|Talk:2025 Nepalese Gen Z protests]] expired 2025-10-31 21:01 ===
* Id: 4E263FB
* User: Robert McClenon
* Date: 2025-10-01 20:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1314517302|HIST 1314517302}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1314517313|SOC 1314517313}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1319782100|HIST 1319782100}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1319782103|SOC 1319782103}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the Safal Committee be mentioned ? {{ordered list |list-style-type=upper-alpha

|In the infobox and in the text of the article?

|In the text of the article but not in the infobox?

|No.


}} Please answer '''A''','''B''', or '''C''' in the Survey with a brief statement.  Please discuss in the Discussion section. [[User:Robert McClenon|Robert McClenon]] ([[User talk:Robert McClenon|talk]]) 20:25, 1 October 2025 (UTC)}}

[[Talk:Fascism#Trumpism_/_MAGA|Editors here]] have discussed findings from the academic community on fascism, which is increasingly characterizing Donald Trump's policies as fascist/proto-fascist/neo-fascist, or that they are leading the US towards fascism. === [[Talk:C data types#rfc_A81C585|Talk:C data types]] expired 2025-11-02 22:01 ===
* Id: A81C585
* User: 24.50.56.74
* Date: 2025-10-22 17:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1318231664|SCI 1318231664}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1320124809|SCI 1320124809}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am seeking requests for comments on the alignment of the pointer asterisk on this page. This was previously discussed at [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Computer science#C/C++ pointer asterisk and null checks]] on "standardising code style" across Wikipedia, but essentially no meaningful conclusion was reached: other editors only dismissed the idea of standardising the code. For this reason, I am taking it directly to the talk page to discuss whether we should use left-alignment or right-alignment of pointers.
* Left-alignment: <code>Type* a;</code>
** Proponents of left-alignment will argue that the implication is that <code>a</code> is of type <code>T*</code>.
* Right-alignment: <code>Type *a;</code>
** Proponents of right-alignment will argue that the implication is that <code>*a</code> is of type <code>T</code>.
Left-alignment is seemingly most popular in C++, while right-alignment is seen in older C code (don't quote me on this, this is a rough estimate, but anecdotally I have seen a more even split between left and right alignments in C code). 

I personally support using left-alignment, for the following reasons:
* The page is about data ''types''. Pointers are indeed a type in C, the parser will read <code>int* x;</code> (or <code>int *x;</code>) as <code>x</code> having type <code>int*</code>.
* Continuity with C++, where left-alignment dominates. While C is obviously distinct from C++, the contents of this page just as well apply to C++ and are relevant to it. Whereas in C, there is a more event split between left and right alignment, so nothing would be lost really.
* There are cases where right-alignment can imply essentially meaningless statements. For example, <code>void *x</code> would imply <code>*x</code> is of type <code>void</code>, but <code>void</code> does not have any storage in memory and represents an absence. The use of <code>void*</code> in C is to represent a pointer that may point to any type.
* There are places where the alignment of the pointer is potentially misleading. Take, for example:
<syntaxhighlight lang="c">
struct Link {
    void *data; // data of this link
    struct Link *next; // next link; EMPTY_LIST if there is none
};
</syntaxhighlight>
This could easily be interpreted as <code>sizeof(Link)</code> consisting of <code>sizeof(void)</code> (meaningless) and <code>sizeof(Link)</code>, rather than <code>sizeof(void*) + sizeof(Link*)</code>, which is far clearer due to the attachment of the pointer. This example may be more contrived, but I think that it nonetheless is still worthy of consideration for the reader. Obviously it is fair to assume the reader has some competency in programming, but I do think clarity is best and there is nothing lost in clarity by using left alignment, rather than divergence from some existing standards (such as Linux kernel style or K&R which to be honest has some very out-of-date practices). [[Special:Contributions/24.50.56.74|24.50.56.74]] ([[User talk:24.50.56.74|talk]]) 17:10, 22 October 2025 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Pointer (computer programming)#rfc_703BE78|Talk:Pointer (computer programming)]] expired 2025-11-02 22:01 ===
* Id: 703BE78
* User: 24.50.56.74
* Date: 2025-10-22 17:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1318231664|SCI 1318231664}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1320124809|SCI 1320124809}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am seeking requests for comments on the alignment of the pointer asterisk on this page. This was previously discussed at [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Computer science#C/C++ pointer asterisk and null checks]] on "standardising code style" across Wikipedia, but essentially no meaningful conclusion was reached: other editors only dismissed the idea of standardising the code. For this reason, I am taking it directly to the talk page to discuss whether we should use left-alignment or right-alignment of pointers.
* Left-alignment: <code>Type* a;</code>
** Proponents of left-alignment will argue that the implication is that <code>a</code> is of type <code>T*</code>.
* Right-alignment: <code>Type *a;</code>
** Proponents of right-alignment will argue that the implication is that <code>*a</code> is of type <code>T</code>.
Left-alignment is seemingly most popular in C++, while right-alignment is seen in older C code (don't quote me on this, this is a rough estimate, but anecdotally I have seen a more even split between left and right alignments in C code). 

I personally support using left-alignment, for the following reasons:
* This article is specifically about pointers. Using left-alignment is better at, for example, <code>int* a</code> emphasising that <code>a</code> is of type <code>int*</code>. This draws the attention of the reader to the fact that <code>a</code> is itself a pointer to an <code>int</code>, not that the dereferenced value of <code>a</code> is an <code>int</code>. Furthermore, pointers are indeed a type in C, the parser will read <code>int* x;</code> (or <code>int *x;</code>) as <code>x</code> having type <code>int*</code>.
* There are cases where right-alignment can imply essentially meaningless statements. For example, <code>void *x</code> would imply <code>*x</code> is of type <code>void</code>, but <code>void</code> does not have any storage in memory and represents an absence. The use of <code>void*</code> in C is to represent a pointer that may point to any type.
* This page is about the general concept of pointers, not pointers in C. Many other languages align the asterisk with the type, including (but not limited to) [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]], [[Rust (programming language)|Rust]], [[Go (programming language)|Go]], among others. Maintaining alignment with the type maintains consistency.
* There are places where the alignment of the pointer is potentially misleading. Take, for example:
<syntaxhighlight lang="c">
struct Link {
    void *data; // data of this link
    struct Link *next; // next link; EMPTY_LIST if there is none
};
</syntaxhighlight>
This could easily be interpreted as <code>sizeof(Link)</code> consisting of <code>sizeof(void)</code> (meaningless) and <code>sizeof(Link)</code>, rather than <code>sizeof(void*) + sizeof(Link*)</code>, which is far clearer due to the attachment of the pointer. This example may be more contrived, but I think that it nonetheless is still worthy of consideration for the reader. Obviously it is fair to assume the reader has some competency in programming, but I do think clarity is best and there is nothing lost in clarity by using left alignment, rather than divergence from some existing standards (such as Linux kernel style or K&R which to be honest has some very out-of-date practices). [[Special:Contributions/24.50.56.74|24.50.56.74]] ([[User talk:24.50.56.74|talk]]) 17:05, 22 October 2025 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a dispute among editors, mainly about whether we should include this sentence ({{tq|He has drawn criticism from scientists for promoting dietary supplements and making "errors of fact"}}) in the [[WP:MOS]] or not. I‚Äôm against including it in the lead, in order to comply with [[WP:BLP]], which requires high-quality secondary sources, not just quotes from experts in the media. Also, since this relates to dietary supplements, I think [[WP:MEDRS]] applies, and there should be at least two direct and in-depth journal articles covering this issue; otherwise, it would be undue to include it in the lead.

I‚Äôd like to get broader community input on this - should we include the above-mentioned sentence in the lead? [[User:Weilins|Weilins]] ([[User talk:Weilins|talk]]) 23:44, 3 November 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Did you know#rfc_E97DE26|Wikipedia talk:Did you know]] expired 2025-11-05 14:01 ===
* Id: E97DE26
* User: Narutolovehinata5
* Date: 2025-10-06 13:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1315407541|POLICY 1315407541}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1320565496|POLICY 1320565496}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should DYK prohibit or restrict superlative hooks, such as those that revolve around a "first X" hook fact?
*'''Option 1''' - Ban all superlative hooks
*'''Option 2''' - Restrict superlative hooks to certain "airtight" cases, where established lists of subject members exist (for example, list of all US presidents)
*'''Option 3''' - Only allow superlative hooks to be approved on a case-by-case basis after a WT:DYK discussion
*'''Option 4''' - Status quo (bringing superlative hooks to WT:DYK is optional but encouraged, not mandatory, hooks do not need a WT:DYK discussion to be approved by a reviewer)
[[User:Narutolovehinata5|<B><span style="color:#0038A8">Naruto</span><span style="color:#FCD116">love</span><span style="color:#CE1126">hinata</span>5</B>]] ([[User talk:Narutolovehinata5|talk]] ¬∑ [[Special:Contributions/Narutolovehinata5|contributions]]) 13:18, 6 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:North Korean Postal Service#rfc_D25F07D|Talk:North Korean Postal Service]] expired 2025-11-05 21:01 ===
* Id: D25F07D
* User: HCCB3947
* Date: 2025-11-05 09:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1320543735|ECON 1320543735}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1320543736|HIST 1320543736}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1320619865|ECON 1320619865}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1320619870|HIST 1320619870}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The ''2000 Sino-DPRK Postal Agreement'' mentioned a new pair of exchange offices, "[[Hunchun]] and ÂÖÉÊ≠£ ([[Pinyin|Chinese pinyin]]: Yuanzheng)". Extensive searches conducted by several Chinese Wikipedia editors (including me) have failed to find any place in DPRK called "ÂÖÉÊ≠£ (Yuanzheng)" along the Sino-DPRK border or throughout the DPRK. Later, @[[User:Hehua|Hehua]] discovered that the DPRK village bordered by [[Hunchun]] is called "Wonj(e)ong-ri" (Chinese: ÂÖÉÊ±ÄÈáå, [[Pinyin|Chinese Pinyin]]: Yuantingli) and "ÂÖÉÊ≠£ (Yuanzheng)" is suspected to be a misspelling of "Wonj(e)ong-ri" (or a previously-used translation, but no supporting evidence has been found).

The FULL name of the agreement is:„Ää[https://treaty.mfa.gov.cn/tykfiles/20180718/1531876876988.pdf ‰∏≠Âçé‰∫∫Ê∞ëÂÖ±ÂíåÂõΩÂõΩÂÆ∂ÈÇÆÊîøÂ±ÄÂíåÊúùÈ≤úÊ∞ë‰∏ª‰∏ª‰πâ‰∫∫Ê∞ëÂÖ±ÂíåÂõΩÈÄí‰ø°ÁúÅÂÖ≥‰∫éÂä†Âº∫ÈÇÆÊîøÈ¢ÜÂüüÂêà‰ΩúÁöÑÂçèËÆÆ]„Äã, or in English: ''Agreement on strengthening cooperation in the postal field between the State Post Bureau of the People's Republic of China and the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea''. <small>(I translate the name personally, according to the Article 9 in the agreement, it's only written in Chinese + Korean languages and no official English version was created)</small>

It is hoped that editor who speaks Korean language can clarify this information by searching for the Korean text of the ''2000 Sino-DPRK Postal Agreement'' in databases like [https://db.history.go.kr/ this], or other reliable methods, to determine the intended referred geographic place of the DPRK that named "ÂÖÉÊ≠£ (Yuanzheng)" in Chinese, so as to establish its standard translation for the English version. [[User:HCCB3947|HCCB3947]] ([[User talk:HCCB3947|talk]]) 09:03, 5 November 2025 (UTC)}}

{{talk quote|Opposition leader [[Rahul Gandhi]] criticised Modi's acceptance of the ceasefire, alleging that it amounted to a surrender under pressure from Trump.[https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/madhya-pradesh/rahul-gandhi-accuses-pm-modi-of-surrendering-to-us-pressure-over-indo-pak-ceasefire/article69653581.ece][https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/trump-said-stop-pm-modi-stopped-rahul-gandhi-renews-attack-over-operation-sindoor-ceasefire/articleshow/121598479.cms]}}

=== [[Talk:Copenhagen Consensus Center#rfc_F28539F|Talk:Copenhagen Consensus Center]] expired 2025-11-09 00:01 ===
* Id: F28539F
* User: Viriditas
* Date: 2025-11-07 21:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

=== [[Talk:Military‚Äìindustrial complex#rfc_9F1C09F|Talk:Military‚Äìindustrial complex]] expired 2025-11-12 21:01 ===
* Id: 9F1C09F
* User: Uhoj
* Date: 2025-10-13 20:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1316669082|HIST 1316669082}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1316669086|LANG 1316669086}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1316669087|POL 1316669087}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1321815036|HIST 1321815036}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1321815039|LANG 1321815039}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1321815042|POL 1321815042}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which should we use: A or B?

'''A''': The speech was authored by [[Ralph E. Williams]] and [[Malcolm Moos]] and was foreshadowed by a passage in the 1954 book ''Power Through Purpose'' coauthored by Moos. The degree to which Eisenhower and his brother [[Milton Eisenhower|Milton]] shaped the speech is unclear from surviving documents. Planning commenced in early 1959; however, the earliest archival evidence of a military-industrial complex theme is a late-1960 memo by Williams that includes the phrase ''war based industrial complex''. A wide range of interpretations have been made of the speech's meaning. Looking back in 1985, Williams wrote that he was "astonished" at the attention given to the ''military-industrial complex'' [[sound bite]], saying that it "has been distorted beyond recognition{{nbsp}}... it became red meat for the media".<ref name="ledbetter ch5">{{cite book |last=Ledbetter |first=James |date=2011 |title= Unwarranted Influence: Dwight D. Eisenhower and the Military-Industrial Complex |publisher= Yale University Press |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Unwarranted_Influence/rxZ8BPomTlMC?hl=en&gbpv=0 |isbn= 978-0-300-15305-7 |chapter=5: The Speech |pages=106-131}}</ref>

'''B''': The phrase was thought to have been "war-based" industrial complex before becoming "military", a claim passed on only by oral history.<ref name="ledbetter">{{cite book |last=Ledbetter |first=James |date=2011 |title= Unwarranted Influence: Dwight D. Eisenhower and the Military-Industrial Complex |publisher= Yale University Press |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Unwarranted_Influence/rxZ8BPomTlMC?hl=en&gbpv=0 |isbn= 978-0-300-15305-7}}</ref><sup>:111</sup> [[Geoffrey Perret]], in his biography of Eisenhower, claims that in one draft of the speech, the phrase was "military‚Äìindustrial‚Äìcongressional complex", indicating the role that the United States Congress plays in the propagation of the military industry, but the word "congressional" was dropped from the final version.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Geoffrey |first=Perret |title=Eisenhower |publisher=New York: Random House |year=1999 |isbn=0375500464}}</ref> [[James Ledbetter]] calls this a "stubborn misconception" not supported by any evidence.<ref name="Ledbetter">{{cite web |last=Ledbetter |first=James |date=25 January 2011 |title=Guest Post: 50 Years of the "Military‚ÄìIndustrial Complex" |url=http://schott.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/25/guest-post-james-ledbetter-on-50-years-of-the-military-industrial-complex/ |access-date=25 January 2011 |work=Schott's Vocab |publisher=[[New York Times]]}}</ref> The actual authors of the speech were Eisenhower's speechwriters [[Ralph E. Williams]] and [[Malcolm Moos]].<ref>Griffin, Charles "New Light on Eisenhower's Farewell Address", in Presidential Studies Quarterly 22 (Summer 1992): 469‚Äì479</ref> [[User:Uhoj|Uhoj]] ([[User talk:Uhoj|talk]]) 20:40, 13 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Matcha#rfc_C16A937|Talk:Matcha]] expired 2025-11-16 04:01 ===

{{rfcquote|text=
I did a rough read of the talk page discussion above and believe we have consensus to say that 1) matcha can trace its root ultimately to <del>China</del> <ins>Chinese powdered tea</ins>, and 2) the current form of matcha, which is the primary subject of this article, originated in Japan. I propose we use the following phrasing in the second paragraph {{strike|as suggested by [[User:ËñîËñáÈ®éÂ£´Âõ£]]: {{tpq|Matcha traces its origins to China but was developed into its current form in Japan.}}}} {{tpq|Matcha originated from Chinese powdered tea and evolved into its current form in Japan.}} [[User:Northern Moonlight|<span style="background-color:light-dark(#f3f3fe,#252558);color:var(--color-progressive,#36c);padding:2px 5px;border-radius:3px;white-space:nowrap">Northern Moonlight</span>]] 03:12, 17 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_0A8947D|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2025-11-17 13:01 ===
* Id: 0A8947D
* User: Giuliotf
* Date: 2025-11-16 16:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1322510692|HIST 1322510692}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1322661938|HIST 1322661938}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes the reliability of Maplandia

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].
*'''Option 5:''' The source is:
**'''Generally reliable''' for Place Names and Locations/Coordinates
**'''Generally unreliable''' for Feature Classes, particularly "Populated place"
**Does not satisfy the "Legal recognition" requirement of [[WP:GEOLAND]].
[[User:Giuliotf|Giuliotf]] ([[User talk:Giuliotf|talk]]) 16:11, 16 November 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_21B2E24|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2025-11-17 15:01 ===
* Id: 21B2E24
* User: Zackmann08
* Date: 2025-10-20 22:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1317937388|POLICY 1317937388}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1317937393|PROP 1317937393}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1322676915|POLICY 1322676915}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1322676919|PROP 1322676919}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There have been some perennial discussions about removal of {{para|slogan}} from various infoboxes, but I could not find a case that discussed making [[WP:SLOGAN]] essentially policy. 

In recent years, the slogan parameter has been removed from {{tl|Infobox bus company}}, {{tl|Infobox airline}} and the widely used {{tl|Infobox company}} ([[Template talk:Infobox company/Slogans|see the MANY discussions]] about removing it from Infobox company).

Now [[WP:SLOGAN]] is ''just an essay'' which I know many people object to, but hence the reason for this RFC. I encourage everyone to read the essay but here are the key points (This is copied from [[WP:SLOGAN]])

{{tq|Mission statements generally suffer from some fundamental problems that are incompatible with Wikipedia style guidelines:}}
* {{tq|Even though mission statements are verifiable, they are [[WP:PRIMARY|written by the company itself]], which makes them a primary source.}}
* {{tq|They contain [[Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words|boastful words]] and [[Wikipedia:Avoid peacock terms|puffed-up, flowery language]].}}
* {{tq|They contain vague unsubstantiated claims such as ''We are the industry leaders in commitment to'' &lt;insert industry here&gt; ''excellence''.}}
* {{tq|They focus on the speculation about the [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a crystal ball|future of the company]]: becoming the industry leader, or the top producer, or the most reliable manufacturer.}}
* {{tq|They are [[Wikipedia:Spam|promotional]] in both tone and purpose.}}
* {{tq|They are not usually [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] in [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|third party sources]].}}

Per [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Search&limit=100&offset=0&ns10=1&search=insource%3A%2Fslogan%2F+intitle%3A%2FInfobox%2Fi+-intitle%3A%2F%5C%2F%2F this search] there are at least 37 infoboxes that have some form of slogan in them. The question is should all of those be removed? This does not mean that slogans cannot be mentioned in the body of an article, that is another conversation about whether they meet notability and are encyclopedic. My question is purely ''do they belong in the infobox''?

In addition to this, what about mottos? It seems as though they are used rather interchangeably in Infoboxes... [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special%3ASearch&limit=500&offset=0&ns10=1&search=insource%3A%2Fmotto%2F+intitle%3A%2FInfobox%2Fi+-intitle%3A%2F%5C%2F%2F&searchToken=1psnqsw0imds6n2qi1aqz9cjr This search] shows at least 72 infoboxes with a {{code|motto}} type parameter. Should some of those be removed? Personally I'd say keep it for settlement type infoboxes, but the way it is used on {{tl|Infobox laboratory}} or {{tl|Infobox ambulance company}}, it is performing the same functionality as a slogan and has the same issues. 

Look forward to everyone's thoughts! - '''[[User:Zackmann08|<span style="color:#00ced1">Zack</span><span style="color:#007F94">mann</span>]]''' (<sup>[[User_talk:Zackmann08|Talk to me]]</sup>/<sub>[[Special:Contributions/Zackmann08|<span style="color:orange;">What I been doing</span>]]</sub>) 22:29, 20 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2026 Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly election#rfc_3866BA5|Talk:2026 Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly election]] expired 2025-11-17 16:02 ===
* Id: 3866BA5
* User: Anbarasan1523
* Date: 2025-11-10 16:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1321454225|POL 1321454225}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1322685068|POL 1322685068}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The current content in background section is lengthy and have promotional tone. I have summarised the content, particularly removed the statements made by the government instead of other unbiased sources, to ensure [[WP:NPOV]] and gave equal weight on both sides. [[Talk:2026 Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly election#Suggested edit on background|My edit above]] is just a suggestion. I request you all to contribute for improving the content. [[User:Anbarasan1523|Anbarasan1523]] ([[User talk:Anbarasan1523|talk]]) 16:35, 10 November 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:QOR360#rfc_FD7BDCD|Talk:QOR360]] expired 2025-11-17 21:01 ===
* Id: FD7BDCD
* User: Brucemyboy1212
* Date: 2025-10-24 18:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1318580616|ECON 1318580616}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1322730482|ECON 1322730482}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a dispute over whether the article contains promotional language and merits a warning template. [[User:Brucemyboy1212|Brucemyboy1212]] ([[User talk:Brucemyboy1212|talk]]) 18:55, 24 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (government and legislation)#rfc_C31FFE3|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (government and legislation)]] expired 2025-11-17 23:01 ===
* Id: C31FFE3
* User: TheUzbek
* Date: 2025-10-30 13:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1319550372|POL 1319550372}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1319550379|STYLE 1319550379}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1322749685|POL 1322749685}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1322749692|STYLE 1322749692}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We need to change the naming convention for elections in communist states. The naming convention, in many ways, does not make sense: the elections, in North Korea, for example, are called [[1959 North Korean parliamentary by-election]]. Does North Korea have a parliamentary system? No, it has a [[supreme state organ of power]] that holds the [[Unified power|unified powers]] of the state. And North Korea is not the exception, but the norm. The communist state election model was formed in opposition to [[parliamentary]], the [[fusion of powers]], and the [[separation of powers]]. In the communist bloc, and in present-day China and North Korea, the term traditionally used is "Election of deputies to the" organ in question, that is, "election of deputies to the National People's Congress" and the "election of deputies to the Supreme People's Assembly". However, in the case of China, this title is problematic: the election process begins at the grassroots and ends with the provincial and other provincial-level people's congresses electing members to the National People's Congress. The entire election process begins at the bottom and goes from each level until it reaches the supreme state organ of power, that is, the National People's Congress.

A more correct, and less controversial title often used is legislative election, as in the [[1984 Soviet Union legislative election]]. But again, that might make it seem like the election process was identical in the US as in the Soviet Union: it was not. I, here, also propose using the formal term used by the communist states themselves: [[1984 Election of Deputies to the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union]] or [[1984 Soviet Election of Deputies to the Supreme Soviet]].

I have several proposals: {{ordered list |list-style-type=upper-alpha

| At the very least, we need to '''STOP''' describing communist state elections as parliamentary. The communist states had [[Supreme state organ of power|supreme state organs of power]] that held the unified powers of the state and monopolised legislative power; that is, let's use the term' legislative' in the article title, as in the 1984 Soviet Union legislative election.

| Take the most radical and correct route. Make clear that communist state elections were different from once in liberal democracies and used different terminology. Follow the WP naming convention, but use terminology used by these states themselves: "1984 Soviet Election of Deputies to the Supreme Soviet" or, for example, "[[2018-19 Chinese Election of Deputies]]"

| Be exceptionally bold, and create a new naming convention for communist state elections: "[[Election of Deputies to the 11th Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union]]" (instead of "1984 Soviet Union legislative election"), "[[Election of Deputies to the 1st People's Chamber of East Germany]] (instead of [[1950 East German general election]]), and "[[Election of Deputies to the 14th Supreme People's Assembly of North Korea]]" (instead of [[2019 North Korean parliamentary election]])

| Status quo, but use the name of the overall body where applicable, [[1984 Soviet of Nations election]].

| [[2019 North Korean supreme state organ of power election]], [[1984 Soviet supreme state organ of power election]], [[1950 East German supreme state organ of power election]]. This is logical as well: they are supreme state organs of power, and keeps the structure intact without making it too complicated.

}} What should be transparent for everybody is the lack of consistency when describing communist state elections, which I hope we can all agree is a bad thing... Since they all practised the same electoral system based on electing lower-level state organs of power and a supreme state organ of power. 

{{replyto|The Account 2|Nikkimaria|JArthur1984|Chipmunkdavis|Jack Upland|Abo Yemen|Easternsahara}} --[[User:TheUzbek|TheUzbek]] ([[User talk:TheUzbek|talk]]) 13:10, 30 October 2025 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_A33CAB7|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2025-11-17 23:01 ===
* Id: A33CAB7
* User: Crouch, Swale
* Date: 2025-11-09 22:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1321326158|STYLE 1321326158}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1326616288|STYLE 1326616288}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (UK Parliament constituencies)]] be further modified to only require "(UK Parliament constituency)" or "(Scottish Parliament constituency)" when there are multiple constituencies such as [[North East Fife (UK Parliament constituency)]] and [[North East Fife (Scottish Parliament constituency)]] and otherwise use [[Clacton (constituency)]] instead of [[Clacton (UK Parliament constituency)]] and [[Orkney (constituency)]] instead of [[Orkney (Scottish Parliament constituency)]]. At [[#RfC on pre-emptive disambiguation in constituency article titles]] there was consensus to move unambiguous articles to the base name such as [[Bury St Edmunds and Stowmarket (UK Parliament constituency)]] to [[Bury St Edmunds and Stowmarket]] but this RFC deals with removing extra disambiguation when the topic does need disambiguation because of a different use such as a settlement or district.
* Pinging people who participated in the previous RfC and have recently been involved {{Ping|162 etc.|Amakuru|Andrew Gray|DankJae|DimensionalFusion|Doktorbuk|Elli|Extraordinary Writ|JHunterJ|GothicGolem29|Graham11|Mdewman6|ModernDayTrilobite|PamD|Surtsicna|Thryduulf|Yoblyblob}} as well as significantly involved in the 2014 discussion.
* '''Support''' it makes no sense to have a title like [[Clacton (UK Parliament constituency)]] or [[Leeds North West (UK Parliament constituency)]]. While it could be argued that [[Leeds North West (constituency)]] would be helpful as it shows its not about the north west part of Leeds the RFC was clearly against that (of which I agree) but I can see no reason why "UK Parliament" is helpful and at least in England few are ambiguous (as opposed to in Scotland) so few would actually need the longer title anyway so consistency doesn't seem a problem here anyway so [[Georgia (U.S. state)]] would be the exception while [[New York (state)]] and [[Washington (state)]] would be more common. In terms of common usage apart from people saying "MP for Clacton" people do refer to "my constituency" by not "my UK Parliament constituency" of which the latter only seems to get 2 results while the former gets lots of results so I don't see how this is even commonly used extra disambiguation when people need to specify them in real life. '''[[User:Crouch, Swale|<span style="color:Green">Crouch, Swale</span>]]''' ([[User talk:Crouch, Swale|<span style="color:Blue">talk</span>]])  22:03, 9 November 2025 (UTC)}}
